content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Review for Interstellar Marines Update #10LINK TO VIDEO REVIEW: 


YouTube™ Video: GAME REVIEW - Interstellar Marines Update #10 

			Views: 7,062		

			Check out the very first review for Interstellar Marines update #10! This update is a small step in the right direction. Please support these developers by checking out the game on Steam.		

Zero Point Software has proven that nothing will stop them from finishing Interstellar Marines. With long list of development setbacks, managing to get Interstellar Marines to this point is a huge accomplishment. For the past month, Zero Point Software has been working extremely hard to release the latest update for their game, update #10. Is it any good? Well, it’s a step in the right direction.Visuals: At first glance, you will notice some major changes to the visuals. The HUD has been completely reworked, the weapon model has been replaced with a new, modern looking assault rifle, and the overall realism of the environments and their effects all blend together to make a very polished feel. I’ve been killed quite a few times while stopping to watch the environment change its weather cycle because it just looked that good. But, as much as I like the new visuals, the option to turn off the bloom effects has been removed, and while this makes the game fairer for those who would keep these effects on and play with the disrupted vision, the bloom glow effects can sometimes feel overused and disrupt the vision to the point of frustration. It would be nice to see ZPS turn down these effects or balance them more to keep the visual impact, but not make any sacrifices on the game-play side. Also, when you are walking, the HUD moves and bobs so much that it’s almost impossible to see who is on your team or what their score is without completing ceasing all movement. I liked to check how my friends are doing in previous updates but now I feel more excluded.Gameplay: There is no doubt that Zero Point has worked very hard on making the experience in Interstellar Marines as smooth and polished as possible, and it really shows here. With the addition of a crouching and basic cover system in update #10, the tactical element has never felt more important. I’ve never had so much fun hopping from cover to cover with my squad mates. And the excellent improvements to the sound design only add to the overall experience. In one instance, I would be moving from cover to cover with my squad mates to reach the building across, zzwhile being sniped by the enemy team from across the map. It’s moments like these which make Interstellar Marines different and memorable than any other shooter. The more ZPS improves the features in the game, the more the game will feel alive. Sometimes, though, the cover system doesn’t always work. The camera’s height adjustments when popping in and out of cover can feel a bit clunky and switching from crouching to standing to quickly escape gun fire feels too difficult to achieve and ends up in a cheap death. This isn’t a game breaker, but since the cover system is a big deal, after a few matches, the errors start to really stand out and impact my overall experience. With the lack of support for any communication with your squad mates personally in game, players are still forced to communicate through and outside source, which isn’t bad, but just a bit tedious. I understand that this is still an early update for the game, and the developers have promised some sort of squad communication system in the future, so I am looking forward to seeing what they will do with this.Summary: Update #10 is a welcome addition to Interstellar Marines. While it has a few flaws, it’s a step in the right direction. It doesn’t do anything to drastically change the core game-play, but the additional features being added each update is really making a huge difference in the game and the fan base. ZPS has done an amazing job with the game so far, and I can’t wait to see where they take this game. Visuals: 9.3 FANTASTIC VISUALS BUT THE OVERUSE OF BLOOM AND GLOW DISRUPTS GAMEPLAYGameplay: 7.5 CROUCH IS A SOLID IMPROVEMENT, BUT IT DOESN’T ALWAYS WORKAudio: 9 EXCELLENT SOUND DESIGN HELPS PULL YOU INTO THE GAMELasting Appeal: 7.4 VERY FUN, BUT AFTER A FEW MATCHES, THE PROBLEMS START TO SHOWFinal Score: 8.3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines. What can I say? Well, for one, CoD fans REALLY missed out on this one. Second, this review:Interstellar Marines is a sci-fi FPS that has AMAZING potential. I could see this being a revolutionary game in the near future. The devs are very involved with the community, it has a basic attatchment system, and the Co-op robots never seem to stop FREAKING ME THE HELL OUTOHMYGODPLEASEDONTKILLME!But, in all seriousness, this game is a very solid, immersive game, with the only thing that could add to the immersion is Oculus support. The Winter Holidays event is DM with the T-IM101: A christmas-light-filled, yelling, insanely stat-boosted Arnold Shwarzeneggar inside a spacesuit that possesses you when you touch a present. Yeah. The updates also never fail to bring new and interesting content, and you will be on the edge of your seat waiting for the next addition by Zero Pont Software.There aren't many weapons, but after you have the basic weapons (Assault Rifle, Pistol, SMG, Sniper Rifle, maybe a Grenade Launcher as a special pickup, etc.), they should focus on customization & attachments (If they aren't doing that already). The few weapons only adds to the balance and tactical-ness of the game. However, no system is without its... Kinks. Phone Guy said that, and it is very true, especially with Early Access games. The updates DO take a while to come out, so you'll be on the edge of your seat for a while. There is, however, no issue with crashing or glitching as far as I'm concerned. So, TL;DR, a very solid and immersive game with tight shooting, superb graphics, and updates and robots that never fail to impress and scare. Respectively. 10/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is really interesting in the combination of fps and stealth, but there are some things that definitely need to be fixed:1) Framerate. Now I know this is probably just my computer, as I have the same problem with nosgoth, but when I tried to fix the resolution, suddenly all of the buttons registered my mouse only when it was several inches away from the actual button. THIS IS NOT GOOD, but it is a small problem that probably could be fixed with a quick update.2)Lighting. This game is pretty dark, with lights in the levels shutting off randomly, even without me shooting them, and I have no idea if this is on purpose, or a bug. some explanation would be helpful. Also, incorporation of a night vision feature would greatly help, as a flashlight automatically gives me away, and as was previously mentioned, this game is pretty freaking dark.3)Audio. The computer giving me directions in the game sometimes repeats things, and again this is a problem that I'm not sure is intended or not, and if not, this is just another small problem that could be fixed with a quick update, as instruction was sometimes garbled among itself.Overall, though this is a really cool game, with solid controls, decent graphics (for an early access game), and a really cool helmet/HUD feature that entertains me to no end. I would love to see this be a full release and move beyond the early access stage, as this game has a lot of potential.

content:

Early Access Review
								I've been following this game, for a few years; basically I seen mutant land sharks, and well I am still left waiting for it. Lets be honest this game is early access but its good, the basics are there, and the shooting omg, I havent played a game that I feel like Im actually hitting where I aim. Perhaps many will say its unrealistic as there doest seem to have any variation of flight, but damn it feels good to know you as the player are on point.  Where is the game now? Well, its playable with a some bugs that are easily repeatable but nothing that breaks the game. There are 7 maps, and really it doesnt seem like much. And once you clear them all with you group of friends its hard to go back to them. And you will need friends, this game can be hard and failing is a part of it, but with a full group of friends there are alot of tactics to try in all the maps  in all the modes. It just feels like there isnt enough game yet, esp with updates so far between eachother. The online server chooser needs to be fleshed out a bit, currently a slight pain to get a game going, but not hard either, just missing some nicities. So for me and my group, there isnt enough yet for us to buy into I.M.'s Early Access yet. BUT if an update adds the sharks and give me some LAN play, I'm all in. It just need a bit more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines is a fantastic sci-fi 1st person shooter. The developers show that they care by using tons of detail. The enviornments change, from day to night to rain to snow in just a short match. The player has so many decisions to make when this fantastic enviornment changes, you can use a flashlight attachment to your gun, have a laser sight, open and close your helmet visor. For example, in the night you can choose to use your flashlight to find people or you can creep around in the shadows (in the dark.) Another nice feature is you can walk around the maps by yourself and get to them before challenging others. This game is early access so you can imagine there are a few turn-off's as of right now, lag, the campaign has not been added yet, and sadly as far as I know there is only 1 or 2 guns in multiplayer. Overall though I would recommend it, if you are intrested I would purchase this game asap before it becomes to expensive because I think this game has a great future. It is a blast in my opinion similar to Halo and Call of Duty mixed with an amazing fighting enviornment. I would ABSOLUTELY recomend this game to anyone who likes 1st person shooter games.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								*UPDATED OCTOBER 12TH, 2016*Unfortunately, at this time, with the rapid loss of momentum the devs had, I cannot recommend Interstelllar Marines any longer. The developers have been drained to one last man, a very dedicated one at that, but realistically I cannot recommend this game unless things begin to look up once more.At it's core, IM is a tactical shooter that focused on immersive first person experiences in the vein of games such as Rainbow Six. It has relatively solid gunplay, fleshed out movement, and working SP/MP. It is a game that's been fun, that's had potential, but has lost steam as money ran dry, and devs were let go.Kim, don't give up on your dream; but don't forget about your life, please. Perhaps one day, IM will finally live; but for now, it settles in for a long night.For the love of the game.ORIGINAL REVIEW -*HIGHLY SUGGESTED TO TAKE A LOOK AT GAMEPLAY VIDEOS; IT'S A LOGICAL CHOICE*Interstellar Marines is a game I’ve anticipated, forgot, and then, to my great joy, rediscovered 2013 on Steam, fresh from being greenlit. My mind filled with visions of shark-creatures, tactical combat, and more sharks...Unfortunately, that game I saw a few years before is still in early access stages.However, that’s not bad. On the contrary, it’s a good thing, considering all the troubles Zero Point Software has faced even trying to get it to this point. The stuff they’ve been through so far is already an inspiring tale by itself.Note that the following is subject to change and modification as updates roll out and as I improve what I have to say. If you don’t like my review, please, give me some feedback in the comments!The review-	As of writing, the current update (Update 16) features quite a few things, but is missing many more. The game is still rather barebones due to all the indev and inactive features, the guns still possessing infinite ammo and marines still missing some vital things.HOWEVER, even at this pre-alpha stage, Interstellar Marines is a blast.	Tense Player versus Player matches, while not the focus of the game, drip with a fragile surface tension that can be broken violently with gunfire as you try to take points or navigate the map, the immersion being damn great.	The low health, movement style, and unforgiving weaponry contribute to this tense and (semi) tactical gameplay, and will hopefully continue to get better and better as updates are rolled out, and features are added, increasing the number of strategies and tactical moves a team can use to wipe out the opposition, be they Human Players...	Or Combat Training Robots, built to push you to your limit in tense PvE missions, all designed with co-op in mind. Update 13 brought everyone access to fight CTRs proper in the 'Neurogen Incident', the first 'Campaign' mission of IM that has a tense (if glitchy) atmosphere, achieved by setting players in a replica space station and giving them multiple objectives to achieve their way.	Since then, more and more AI missions have been added, with Terrorist-Hunt style elimination missions, or Update 16's new 'Assault on Starcrown Aerospace'.	In terms of the effort and care put into the game, there is a distinct lack of major bugs and issues most of the time, and even then Zero Point Software always listens to the community. The quality of the game is high, especially for early access and Unity Engine, and with a shared vision they've gone far, and seem to be going further. You could mistake their work for a veteran developer’s. Triple-A indie indeed!	Unfortunately, at times it’s a bit challenging to be tactical and immersed like ZPS wants. At the moment there’s no proper teamchat, and a limited number of gamemodes and players (Get on more, damn you).	As for how it runs and looks, this game isn't for low end PCs. Before I upgraded I often had 15 FPS on average. Despite this, the views are spectacular, and the graphics actually play an important part in gameplay, due to the dynamic lighting system, the fog and the storm effects. A map can be pushed into pitch-black due to the said lighting, a player can shoot out lights, you can be spotted using the light, etcetera. Loads of options opened by graphics.	As for the online community, with the exception of teamkillers and some new players, those I’ve seen are mature and understand the game, and despite a somewhat lower population of players, there's still dedicated people playing. Very rarely have I seen someone call anyone a 'hacking noob' or anyone go on generic 'CoD-child rage'.	As for the major story and all that, we’ll just have to wait for the future, and the Carcharodons/landsharks. Glorious landsharks!As for ZPS, you guys are dedicated, and the stuff you’re doing to connect with the community is great. Can’t wait for the future!tl;dr, Even though it’s barebones, it's something to follow, and it plays hard.	Now, as for buying it, I'd personally recommend it to support the devs (I know they need it, for the love of the game!) and purchase it, but if you're not that into early access or 'barebones' gameplay, then you may want to wait a bit.	The price will go up, though, over time.NOTE,	Before you make any decisions, you should go see some gameplay of the current version.Additions:CONCERNING THE LACK OF LANDSHARKS AND CAMPAIGN:This is a bloody early access, and it takes time to recreate those things in Unity. Be patient, there's less than 20 devs, and they first want a solid multiplayer first for you, the player or potential believer! And then, only then, can they begin to focus on the landsharky goodness.Where is the ‘First Immersion’ demo?!It was a small publisher demo created to get them publishers back in 2007-8, demonstrating features on Unreal Engine 3. Unfortunately they can’t release it or work on it due to licensing red tape. However, Xeno-13 will be remade eventually!My feelings on the progress of the game after so long:	They've gone through some stuff, and they hit steam with only two developers. Now, today, they're becoming able to hire more due to steam's early access, which will allow them to slowly speed up development and finally get the game out the gate.	After seeing what some of the Devs had to say, I’ve also learned that the ‘lack of progress’ some people argue is actually lots of unseen progress, and lots of bugfixing going on. You don’t see the badass ninja from that one VLog anywhere in the game because they actually fixed that BEFORE updating the game!More/Outdated responsesI see how some complain that the game did not deliver, lied in it's advertising and all that. I say that when you look at the big picture, with all of ZPS' troubles, experiences, and traits, that the advertising was in no way false at the time it was made. Original trailer, made to impress and to get a publisher, but from what I remember they didn’t say it was really ingame. Space Station and Sharks gameplay, a demo built on the Unreal 3 engine to impress and get a publisher, before 2008 screwed them over.Why does the current game look and play so differently than the demo? They can't use the Unreal 3 engine, the license costs a million bucks. That and the assets are a bit dated, and more legal tape.There's more, but I believe this illustrates my point.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's incredible on how this game is so realistic, yet still in it's developing stages. There are multiple maps with envorinment settings. So you can go to one server with a map and it's raining, and as you play in the map the weather actually changes to where it'll be easier to fight, or to where it'll be harder to fight.-Weaponry/Equipment: At this time, there is only 1 weapon, which is an assault rifle. Yet, you also have the abiloity to activate a lazer for you to help with your accurasy, a flashlight incase it get's dark (game sometimes has you in pitch black darkness), of course you can zoom in by right-clicking, and unlike any sci-fi FPS, you can actually take off your visor. So it'll be like fighting with literally your own eyes. But the game doesn't give you a cursor to aim with like Halo, Battlefield, TF2, etc. You actually have to aim like everyone does in real life when in combat.-Maps: There are multiple maps that go from the middle of a swamp, to the cold regions, to a colony in the forest. All maps has the ability to change the weather to throw off players.-Game Mode: So far, there is only one game mode where you hold a certain area for the longest, but as time goes on, the capture zone will move into a different area of the map. In order to win, you must hold the capture zone for the longest when the time runs out, or when the amount of time you hold it reaches it's max. Either way, you have to work with your team in order to win. Cooperation and skill will bring you to victory in this game.Overall, this game is incredible for it to be an Early Access Game, I recommend this game to anyone that reads this.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								In its current state it is a very good game. The only thing that bothers me is its unoptimized state in which it is, but since it is in early access I'll let it slide for now. Singleplayer:Before I installed the game I read reviews about it and saw that people got scared while playing singleplayer.At first I was confused as to how a shooter with robots can be scary. Then I played the singleplayer and I understood.It's pretty scary when a robot starts to run towards you. Although they may seem non-frightening, their faceless head can spook you once it randomly pops up in front of you.Co-op:Didn't play so I can't comment on that, sorry.Multiplayer:The multiplayer for Interstellar Marines was quite fun for me actually, although in my past I played only CoD multiplayer(long time ago). To be honest it took me a little to get used to the guns(only 2 for now) and the lack of crosshair(instead you use a laser), but because of this I was forced to focus on my little tiny dot and I was sucked into the game. The game for now has a small amount of maps, but the ones that are in it currently are very well designed and I look forward to future maps. The players that I played with didn't chat alot so but the ones that did were very nice. I would recommend this game to the people who love strategic shoters as it involves alot of tactical cooperation between players, if you want to win ofcourse.Although I played the game while it was free for a couple of days, I will buy it as soon as I get money as it is worth the money and the wait for better optimization.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you're looking to buy Inserstellar marines as of today: December 2nd 2014I'd recommend this in some circumstances.The game is fun and offers a base-level immersive tactical experience while maintaining just the right level of arcade influence.The graphics are excellent, considering the low texture fidelity, continues to prove that lighting can pretty much make or break a game as far as visual fidelity is concerned. Neurogen Incident certainly shows this off, creating a tense co op experience.The UI can be a bit cumbersome, as I understand that it's meant to be immersive it can still prove to be a pain given the amount of time a chat message appears on screen. Thus forcing you to bring up the chat menu, I'd prefer if they showed all messages from the past 5-10 seconds and slowly faded them out based on lifetime. Making the social experience a bit less frustrating.Something to be noted is the gunplay is not like anything I've experienced it's hard to describe really any other way than it feeling like you're controlling something and it has a considerable latency. Keep in mind my setup has no latency issues monitor is 1ms response time graphics card is more than capable... etc. Not to mention in the game's current state the community is quite small, it's hard to keep an audience's attention when you have such little content to show for, regardless of the content's magnitude.All this taken into consideration also with the fact that this game is still early access, the game is quite unique and definitely delivers an FPS experience unlike anything else I have had. I'd certainly recommend this to a friend who was looking for a basic and immersive tactical FPS for PC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has some amazing potential. Despite the (current) lack of content, the dev team has already nailed the atmosphere of Dead Space cross Rainbow Six , with some surprisingly immersive gameplay and gorgeous graphics from the Unity Engine. Your player character is very human-slow, vulnerable, and brave. Teamwork is just as important as twitch reflexes and awareness of your enviroment, and while the game can be played alone it is difficult and boring without at least someone else by your side. The game currently fearures a decent Multiplayer experience, several solo challenge missions, and two epic story missions pitting you and a team of 3 others up against intelligent and dangerous training robots simulating events from the IM backstory. While many features such as more guns (currently only 2), missions, and enemies (Land Sharks), the game feels balanced and very well done. According to the devs, this has been tehir life's dream for almost 20 years now, and they are very unlikely to give up and leave this as vaporware. The one complaint I have is the development cycle: with only 12 people building the equivalent of a AAA-quality title, it takes several months to update the content. If you're willing to wait, gab the game and start playing-realistic difficulty is hard and takes a lot of cooperation and skill to complete, so don't excpet to be bored. And if it feels too risky, keep an eye on Interstella Marines-this game is going places.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you're like me, you've probably lost interest in shooters the likes of Call of Duty several years ago. Tactical shooters seem to have passed into history and games like the Rainbow Six series have no equals in today's gaming landscape. Interstellar Marines is an admirable attempt to ressurect this genre and is absolutely brimming with potential. In it's current state the game is lacking in both content and polish. There's a few weapons, a handful of maps and some single player content that feels like a tutorial. There are no real tactical options yet and simple features like peeking around a corner are lacking. Still the game is an absolute thrill to play. I found myself holding my breath while sneaking through a futuristic compound, listening for robotic footsteps and checking every corner. The game is every better when played in co-op mode. Interstellar Marines has a long way to go to become a complete and finished project but the potential is there.PRO's:- True TFPS atmosphere- Movement and shooting feel rigid- Fun co-op and Versus MultiplayerCON's:- Inconsistent performance- Incosistent level of polish- Overall lack of conent

								as always thanks for the free weekend guys.i saw alot of tools and playground stuff to toy with and wish i had the time but currently am knee deep in another fps co-op game and decided to give this a shot before the free week ran out.actually pretty suprised and glad i snuck it in there.there's not alot of cosmetically attractive indie fps games out there, but there's some talent at this studio. i'd say the game is not quite a $300 million dollar masterpiece, but it's certaintly on par with the best THQ could put out before their demise. and im sure this was made on far more sweat and alot less cash. the sounds are also fairly solid too. nice little package here.chief complaints?- sever ping was kind of wonky. i had full ping to austrailia? not a chance.more than likely thats steam and/or my internet provider. so can't ding them for that.-no controller support as of yet.  it would've been nice. im sure it'll get added in. maybe ill give it another try then. im sure some people that made this game will be getting phone calls from the big leauges very soon.

content:

								I've been following Interstellar Marines for close to 5 years now. I remember it caught my eye on ModDB. Fast foward to 2015 and the amount of content has barely shifted from that initial concept stage. Hell, I'd say the majority of the concepts first portrayed still aren't present in the game itself and it's hard to say if they ever will be. That, in of itself, is enough to push me to make a "negative" review.A sci-fi, story driven tactical FPS is what this game was supposed to be about. You'll be getting a semi-decent multiplayer arena FPS with two guns instead. Believe me, the groundwork is there, it's just not going anywhere fast. It's simply not worth the 20 dollars it asks for.I won't lie, this was in many ways a bitter disapointment to me as my hopes were high and the concepts/ideas lured me in for many, many years. It just seems like by the time we actually see the game progress in any meaningful manner we will all be experiencing mid-life crisis.

They maybe here, or there or attack you if they see you.Very creepy.very imersive.it"s early access at the moment and darn good already, more to come. This game is totally different.free to roam anywhere and the enemies will follow or react to your flashlight,or lazer. it's just a great game all around, and as I said it's getting better all the time. The developers are really engaged and hard at work on some of the suggestion from the community which is also great.An experience well worth the small price of the game. i give it 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								As an Early Access game, it has managed to keep my attention ever since its initial release. The game has come a long way since its initial release, and the updates are starting to come in faster and faster. If one wants to know how far this game has come, check out videos of the original release vs the current game version (Update 18 for the time this review was written). In terms of gameplay, here is what players can expect to see (As of Update 18):Solid gunplay mechanics. the weapon's sights aren't "glued" to your screen, and will move around as you walk, fire, etc. (Think kind of like Red Orchestra). The weapon does reset at the centre of your screen however.A stamina system that affects your character's accuracy as he gets tired. Stamina is drained when jogging, sprinting, and jumping. You can hear your character's breathing and when your HUD is offline, his breath will fog up the inside of the helmet. An intuitive crouching system that allows you to change stance between a low crouch or a higher stance to shoot over low walls. Aiming down sights will also make your character peek over cover, and if you change stance while aiming, he will only bend at the knees for faster movement. Sprint, Jog, and walk. Three movement speeds that are very useful and easy to cycle through.Two weapons. An Assault Rifle for long range combat and an SMG for close range combat. The ability to attach a sound suppressor to your weapon. It actually works really well in both multiplayer and co-op/single playerYou can shoot out lights to create darkness in order to sneak around (Think Metro 2033/ Last Light)Multiplayer maps will change time of day, weather, and sometimes layout as you play. Matches have a sense of unpredictability for newcomers because of this.Three game modes to chose from: Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, and Domination.3 campaign missions, and a few other side-missions. Currently, all missions are training excercises for your character (A new recruit to the Interstellar Marines).HUD deactivates when you take 50% damage. This makes it hard to identify between friend and foe because IFF markers and objective markers all vanish. I hope that this review has convinced at least one person to try out the game. Despite all the praise I'm throwing at it, note that there are many missing features in the game. The updates have been coming in more quickly recently, and a big one is apparently going to be coming in soon. So if you feel like taking a risk and betting on this extremely promising title, I highly suggest that you buy it. If you can, go for the spearhead edition to get a few extra goodies.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now, this is my first review for Interstellar Marines and it's still an early access game, so there can be some changes in my opinion.Alright, so far Interstellar Marines seems to have great potential in becoming one heck of an awesome sci-fi FPS game. I bought the game's Spearhead edition and immediately looked at all the references they used to model the Marines, and I was amazed that there were references of Halo's SPARTANs and the Halo 4 era Marines in there. I really liked those designs, so the developers could be trying to appeal to those who like the aesthetics of Halo (such as me).The multiplayer matches, however, seem to be VERY unbalanced, as long-time players are always mowing down crowds of new and inexperienced players, which makes this game a bit unfair for newcomers, but the connection to those servers is simply fantastic. I haven't found myself lagging yet and I doubt I ever will. Another thing that bugs me about the gameplay is the constant and wild shake of the weapon. I highly doubt any highly-trained Marine would shake his weapon around like that and even if it's for the purpose of gameplay balance, it's poorly executed and thus makes the players lose valuable long-range accuracy.Also, there is the issue of hacks appearing for the game. These hacks, however, are not as bad as in most FPS games, like, say, Counter Strike or Call of duty, but they still present a significant problem.All of that, though, does not stop me from enjoying this well-made game. I can clearly see that the developers have been trying to create their own great sci-fi shooter and they're doing a pretty good job at it. I highly recommend this game for anyone who is looking for a change from the rage-inducing Call of Duty, the military sim ArmA, or just Battlefield... or just for those who want to test out their skills in multiplayer.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have only played the single player so far but from what i have played i am really liking this game. the main things that make this game fun for me  are:1. there is no mini map to show where the bad guys are2. there are no checkpoints so if you die , you start over on the mission3. i feel the aiming and handling of the weapons is super smooth and just feels really good4. these 3 things together make for a slow paced, very tactical shooter where you must move slow and constantly check the environment around you to not end up dead and back at the start.5. terminator robots, who don't like those?6. realistic mode is very challenging seeing as you will die from one hit from the robots, but very satisfying when your able to pick off the enemies and progress.7. the dark creepy environment where its best to leave the fllashlight off and only use it briefly to get a quick view of your surroundings. to me it keeps me on edge and my heart pounding.8. the devs are in the forums answering questions and making sure they stay civil and trying to keep the trolls and flamers outin conclusion i say give this game a shot it's free for the week so you have nothing to lose especially as it's only 1gb to download so like 2minutes of your time. i's not gonna be for everyone but if you like tactical games where you don't just run around like some movie hero who can't be hurt it might be for you. I'll add more once  i have tried co-op and mp. plus i know for $6 i will get my monies worth even if it takes the devs a while to finish it.edit: im thinking checkpoints on the easiest difficulty might be nice just so you can figure out how to complete a mission without dying after 2hrs not knowing if you were close to the escape or in the entirely wrong spot, but i hear they might be coming

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								My first ten minutes in Interstellar Marines:Start the game.Get my nerves set on edge by the almost unnecessarily creepy training.Go to final stage for training.Shoot the robots.Get the living crap scared out of my by a robot standing right behind a door.Fall complete in love whith this game.IN ALL SERIOUSNESS:This game is really a gem.  It is the best tatical FPS I think I have ever played.  Suck it CoD.  True, it needs more guns, and the huge outdoor maps are kind of laggy, but these small flaws are easily made up for in the truly immersive multiplayer, incredibly tense single player, and the great (and I mean GREAT) co-op.  This game creates so much fear and the chemistry is so good with all the different variables in each mode.  You can shoot the lights out, put silencers on your guns and use lazer sights or flashlights in missions and in multiplayer.  All of these options create their own pros and cons in a mission.  This is a truly great game, and I think that it and it's genre deserve more respect and attention.

I bought the game's Spearhead edition and immediately looked at all the references they used to model the Marines, and I was amazed that there were references of Halo's SPARTANs and the Halo 4 era Marines in there. I really liked those designs, so the developers could be trying to appeal to those who like the aesthetics of Halo (such as me).The multiplayer matches, however, seem to be VERY unbalanced, as long-time players are always mowing down crowds of new and inexperienced players, which makes this game a bit unfair for newcomers, but the connection to those servers is simply fantastic. I haven't found myself lagging yet and I doubt I ever will. Another thing that bugs me about the gameplay is the constant and wild shake of the weapon. I highly doubt any highly-trained Marine would shake his weapon around like that and even if it's for the purpose of gameplay balance, it's poorly executed and thus makes the players lose valuable long-range accuracy.Also, there is the issue of hacks appearing for the game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								No. This is like playing Counter-Strike. You have only 2 guns and they both work the same way. Lots of problems. Still very Early Access and not worth buying. The main PvP game mode is Point Capture. Objective is to capture all 7 points or eliminate all opposing team members. If you die, it will take you 120 seconds to respawn or your surviving teammate can capture a point and give you an instant respawn.This game isn't as polished as it claims to be, do not listen to the marketing bots. I think they just pay bots/people to spam positive reviews for them.PROS1. HUDVery interesting. No need to keep pressing Tab to see who's alive and dead. Doesn't block your view either. Everything in the top left and top right.2. Moving mapsSome parts of the map move up and down, changing the terrain. CONS1. MatchmakingYou have to manually find a game that is of a suitable ping, the map you want and hopefully with players.2. Map DesignLots of map design flaws. Step heights, stairs, handrails... You name it, they got it.3. DoorsEvery single door must be opened by pressing E. No automatic door sensors. There's an Open-Door simulator in this game. Don't try it.4. Night / DarknessWhat's this? A stealth game in the shadows? Bust the gamma on my computer to see my enemy?5. Rain / SprinklersNo. Giving me a wet HUD does not impress me.6. JumpingYou will start panting if you keep jumping. Most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.7. WeaponsOnly 2 at the moment. Both seem to work like Counterstrike rifles.8. BackpacksWhy do the models have backpacks?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								First impression: What a FPS should be. Having cut my game teeth on Wolfenstien,Doom and Quake in ID's shareware beginnings, I found this game to be a great step forward. It is not easy, but if it is easy it soon lacks fun and challenge. I am having a bit of control issues as it is more real in its physcis than the average game of today. Also I have just recently returned to using a mouse as opposed to a trackball and am still getting used to moving the mouse around. The A.I. of the N.P.C. 's (currently robots) is excellent and random in nature, much like hunting humans.  I only have played a few hours so far, but expect to spend a good deal more time in the future. An odd note on server selection is though I reside in the intermountain west the best ping times are to the EU servers, far better times than the US West or East servers. The learning curve is quick and simple with only 2 weapons , however unlike most current shooters there is no auto reload when the guns go empty. Also there is a limit to sprint and jump functions so there is no hopping to avoid fire(yeah) and sprint is soon exhausted (just like for real).  In summary it is well worth watching this one , It should prove to be interesting to see where it goes and hope it does not fall apart as BulletRun did (i really liked that one). at this early stage I would say {7 of 10}. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								A realistic FPS.You die in one or two shots. But can be revived by teammates if they are close.Please note that my review soley focuses on Multiplayer and does not include the story missions as i havent tried them.The game features rather fast, combat but asks the player to be sneaky. The good part: This actually works. You find yourself carefully going through each room, sprinting over open areas and crawling through bushes.The map design first struck me as cheap. Until i played 2 minutes and realized that the maps are constantly changing while you are in it. Every map does it differently. Most maps change daytime and weather conditions (pitchblack night to rainy day in 5 seconds). Other maps lock certain doors and activate different lights. Yet another map actually elevates/decends entire buildings a floor up/down.Now for the game and respawn mechanics, which after the maps is the best part.The goal  is to either clear the map from the enemy teams players (killlsssss) or having control over all the capture points. The respawn timer is 2 minutes. Yep. 2 MINUTES. But thats not bad at all, if your team is capable, because if someone captures a point, one teammate respawns, circuimventing the timer completly. Should someone end up being the last one alive and gets a kill, that will spawn one teammate back into the game as well.The order of respawn is first in first out (or rather first out first back?), so if you die first in the team, you will be the first one to be back in game as well.In many ways it reminds of Insurgency, but it has no lying down, no looking around the edges, plus its respawn/capture mechanic is pushing you torwads more aggressiv play. It feels more action packed then Insurgency in that matter, but has less depth. Yet its not inferior. Lets put it like this: If Insurgency was to slow for you this might be exactly your thing.As its early access, i'ld love to say this: Some more maps, another gamemode maybe, and at least some skins or whatev for your guy and guns when you level up. The game lacks any real progression, and i think new guns would hurt the gameplay more then they would help it. So focusing on skins would be better.If you mistrust Early Access, dont buy it. But otherwise its already very promising.'nuff said.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								The state it's currently in, there's not much to experience in Interstellar Marines. I've only played multiplayer, however. You are given two guns, one for close to mid-range combat, another for mid to long-range. Both guns can have silencers, flashlights, and laser sights toggled.There aren't that many maps yet, which is super understandable, but the maps that are provided are extremely balanced. Maybe too balanced for some, but balanced nonetheless. The maps also change over the course of each round, which is extremely interesting. Platforms move up and down, rain starts to fall (muffling the sound of your footsteps), and the lighting changes. One of my favorite things about this is when the lights go out. Fighting in the dark is insanely satisfying. You never really know what's going on... but in a good way.There's a quite a few bugs here and there, but it's in alpha. Of course there's bugs. This game has a hell of a lot of potential; it looks like it could become the FPS I've been waiting for.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								In it's current state, I DO NOT reccommend this game. However, based on what the devolpers have planned and how frequently the updates are coming along I think it will be a good game in the long run. Let's get to the Pro's and Con's of the game so far. {I PLAN TO UPDATE IT}===PRO===1. The game looks great and runs great, even on some of the lowest settings. The enviroment changes really do add to the combat experience.2. Immersion. The devolpers have been trying to make this game really immersive, and they really have. The rain on the helmet, the ambient sounds, everything about the immersion is great. Once the Oculus Rift support for this game arrives, this will be a MUST-OWN for anyone with an Oculus Rift3. Planned features. This may not seem like a real Pro, but the features the developers want to add sound great. Land Sharks, need I say more? ===CON===1. Only one gun. Gets very boring using the same gun (THOUGH IT IS IN ALPHA, AN EARLY ALPHA). No sidearms, no melee, just your one SMG.2. No hit markers, and the gun feels like it does no damage. Kinda feels like shooting at ghosts until they fall over.3. Only 2 gamemodes (yet again, it's early alpha) Free For All (feels like CoD with one gun) and Team Domination. Team Domination is great mode because it forces teams to work together to hold areas. Sometimes however...4. TEAM KILLING! Your team mates are only marked with little blue lights. Sometimes it can be hard to see if someones on your team, exspecially if they open fire on you.Not gonna rant on how there's no melee or crouching yet in the game, because, once more, it's EARLY ALPHA!In short, Interstellar Marines in it's current state isn't great, but hopefully in a few months it will be well worth the $15.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Tried out the game on the free weekend, have the following thoughts:Someone was complaining in a negative review that the free weekend was the stupidest marking decision they could have made. That is just complete and utter garbage. Especially for early access games there should always be a free weekend if for nothing else but to simply let people try the game in the current state. But in addition to that, and regarding the comment about it being the stupidest decision, all I can say is that steam seems to promote some games and burry others. The fact that this one got a whole free week was a great boost for them I am sure. Hopefully this boost will push the development to the next level, and hopefully the devs can add some critical features to the game and address some of the issues which I will outline below.After playing the game for most of the free week I have the following observations in no particular order:Character Control – overall as good as can be expected with the exception of jumping. Your player just feels weighted down. Maybe this is intended, but I found myself frustrated with the lack of fluidity and height in the jump. I would like to see it be where you can jump over some of the cover items in the game such as the concrete barriers and such. And do this in the heat of combat. As it is now, it’s just not very natural feeling and cumbersome. Because of this I rarely even use jump in the game.Gameplay – A nice variety of mission types with some interesting features. First time I played on a level where the entire area had parts that would raise and lower opening new paths and blocking pervious paths it gave me pause and I had to stop for a minute to marvel at it. Makes for some very tough tactical situations. I like the elimination missions in coop the most, but once you play them a few times it gets stale as you learn where many of the bots spawn from and quickly develop a strategy to beating them, alone or as a team. Not much else in the game at the moment other than bots and not sure if this is by design or because it’s simply not implemented yet but you have infinite ammo. Still have to reload, but you never run out. Still looking for the role play and rainbow-6 tactical elements, but maybe it’s too early for that stuff. The stealth element seems to work well for the most part. Stay low and in the shadows and the bots seem to overlook you. Fire your weapon without a silencer and they will come running to your position. The bots also can home in on you by spotting your flashlight and laser pointer, so you need to know when to use them and when not to.Coop – This is the area that I would really like to see improved the most. I have two major complaints here. 1) absolutely no recourse for griefers and during the time I have played there have been many, many little sh!ts that have nothing better to do than to f-up your game. That and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥s who want to come in and hijack the server you are playing on. I know they said this is coming but come on, at least give us a group kick vote option or something in the meantime. 2) coop needs more elements to encourage team work. As of now, you get no points for reviving a teammate and communication is terrible. The few people who I have heard using a mic it was terrible, and chat totally blows. Why would you make your chat screen have to be opened with a key press and then cover the entire field of view? The chat interface needs a complete overhaul and we need team quick commands. That would be a good start to making it more tactical. If they want to do something original, give us hand signal animations that we can map to the number keys or something. That would really make stealth tactical. I would also like to see a post-game summary. As of now, when the mission is done, you don't get to see anything.Levels - Some people complained about how dark some of the levels are. Yes it’s dark and in some cases I think they take it to the extreme, but it definitely makes the levels interesting and challenging in some cases. I hope the light balancing will be tweaked to be more fun and less frustrating in some cases, but over all its not terrible. The bots don’t like it either; it makes it harder to see you!Content – Aside from the static décor and the bots there’s really nothing else in the game yet. There are interactive doors, some power switches you need to turn on for some missions and lights that you can shoot out. I hope things are added such as ammo, first aid items, of course different weapons, and the typical things you would expect in a shooter. Oh and there is also some background chatter on the intercom, as well as a female voice that gives you some mission instructions from time to time. Interesting to note, it seems like some of the intercom chatter might be alluding to events we might actually see in the finished game. That would be cool.Weapons – As many people have already said, the weapons that are in the game are pretty good, handle well and cover long range and CQB combat. Nothing special here.All in all the game has potential. I have heard that it has been in development for a long time, something like 2 years, so it seems to be going slow. I hope the pace picks up. I do recommend the game if you like the genre and the setting, but I’m not gonna go full fantard and try to convince you that they have all these fabulous features planned all you have to do is wait for it. I really don’t know what’s going to come of this game, but while it’s on sale, why not. I am sure I, as well as you, have wasted more on less so give it a shot… maybe the extra cash will help them realize the potential of this game.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine this: "Player 1 has decided to pull the plug". Everything goes dark except your hud lights and small blue arrows, indicating your allies. Some fluorescent tape on the containers strained in the hallway. You lift your helmet and look around you. You hear distant footsteps and beeping of the computers. You breath deeply and flick your flashlight for a second. A slight movement startles you. As you lower your helmet, you are assecured that that is indeed your friend, your guide in this blue, subtle darkness that engulfs your field of view, and forces you to scout your surroundings. Was that an enemy or a lone wire? Was that a footstep or a drop of water from the sterile, metal ceiling? Suddenly, you hear gunfire, not so distant but not too close. You rush towards the sound and you are greeted with a grim reminder that you have enemies, and their hands are faster than yours. You spray bullets on their shiny costumes and boom, bam, tak! Lo, and behold, they are no more. You huddle your hands around your keyboard in solumn satisfaction: "lol get rekd noobz"

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even for a game that's in it's pre alpha stages, it's a very good game. Don't get me wrong. Like all games in existence, this game has it's fair share of problems. You really can't expect much from a game that's currently in alpha, or pretty much ANY game at all since every game as I've stated before has their own set of issues.As of right now, the game is very lackluster and barebones, but again, you really can't expect too much from an alpha, so have caution if you're expecting this game to give you a lot because as of right now, there's not too much for this game to offer at the moment in it's current stage considering it's an early access title.Another issue I've come across, which I'm still confused on determining what exactly the issue is that's causing this. Regardless, hit detection is another issue (when I'm not in U.S. servers). Any combination of these three reasons could be the cause: Netcode issue, tickrate issue, server location. But again, since it IS an alpha title, I can't really expect it to be perfect considering this game has been in the works slowly for the past decade, which definitely tells you how much the developers care if they're taking their time to perfect their game.One other issue is engine optimization. The graphics, while great, are also very simple, and with simple graphics, I shouldn't be having such huge FPS fluxuations with my FPS dropping as low as 10 FPS at times. Now, the prototypes of the different game modes on the official Interstellar Marines website (especially Bullseye, which ran at a solid 60 FPS for me) looks, sounds, plays, and runs much better than what we currently have on Steam (again, alpha stage, you can't really expect much) which tells me that they're probably taking the DayZ route of things and most likely going to change engines in the future to a more optimized, a more playable engine. Again, it's an alpha. Not only is this game an alpha, but Zero Point Software is an independant game development company. You gotta start somewhere. Gotta be patient with this one considering how careful the devs are being and how delicate they're treating this game. Obviously, this game still has a lot of work to be done, but it's still great nonetheless for an alpha. Pretty much, most of the issues we're seeing currently is due to it's alpha status, which really NO game as an alpha or even a beta can avoid. It's just part of early access games and development. It's natural and it takes time.Regardless, the game is great, and the prototypes of the different game modes on the official Interstellar Marines website are also fantastic as well, which pretty much gives you a taste or a hint of what's to come with this game in the future.Although this game has been in development since 2004, I'd rather a game take 10 years to develop just so it can be perfect and up to it's full potential as opposed to having a broken game released to me that clearly isn't finished yet *coughcoughBADCOMPANY2coughcoughCALLOFDUTYcoughcoughBATTLEFIELD4*.With that being said, I'd really suggest supporting Zero Point Software as much as possible considering they've been busting their asses off for the past 10 years just to dish out a good game, and that right there tells you that these developers take this seriously and pour every ounce of their tears and blood into this game.Get this game. If not now as an pre alpha, get it as a full release when it's finally complete.UPDATE: As of now, many of these issues I mentioned earlier have been resolved by the devs, all the more reason to get this game seeing as the devs actually give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about their game.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a fantastic early access game. Well worth the price and an essential purchase if you see it discounted.The game really shines when working with teammates over VOIP. We played it for hours and had a blast.Pros - Good atmosphere        - No grenades        - Excellent lighting dynamic. This especially keeps things interesting and dynamic.        - Nice map design        - Excellent respawn dynamic, get a kill or capture a capture point to respawn a dead team mate.Cons - Current joining onto the same team of your friends can be a bit difficult, You can only switch teams at the end of each match even if teams are uneven.         - Limited content for single or solo (no VOIP buddies) players.         - Spawn points can be camped. Something needs to be done about this.I recommend grab it and support the developers.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game's dynamic shifts would probably stand out as the main bullet point of the back of the Interstellar Marine box. It changes everything. Suddenly the rain is teaming down, thudding off the helmet of your suit, meaning that running suddenly becomes viable, your loud footsteps masked by the sound of the rain. As the simulation changes again the rain might stop, but the light might abandon you. When it does players are forced to use flashlights for navigation, but open themselves, and their locations, up to attack.It’s this single mindedness that marks Interstellar Marines out as more than just a standard first person shooter. This doesn’t feel like a game that is going to♥♥♥♥♥superfluous nonsense to it to draw in a crowd of Call of Duty gamers. Granted, not doing so could be detrimental to the game’s sales, but, as with the game itself, sticking to their guns and being deliberate in both message and content could attract a dedicated and loyal base.http://www.coffeebreakgaming.co.uk/pc-games/early-access-investigations-interstellar-marines/

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I saw this game online on a game website years ago and made an account and played the free training course and target shooting the game offered. I always wanted this game after I saw it and would always be checking on updates and what the devs were doing, the concept and idea of the game was amazing and sounded like a new amazing co-op and maybe horror game with an optional PVP mode but the soul of the game would be the amazing story and co-op/single player gameplay. Then back to 2013, I saw the game finally went on to steam early acces and was excited and instantly bought the spearhead edition and gave the free key to a friend. We played and checked it out, it was only pvp on like 2 or 3 maps but I didn't care, it was early access and just released so I still had hope and faith in this game. Then came some time after early access release, more PVP updates...still nothing for co-op, even more time, they finally released something..a small concept of co-op is what it seemed like, it was fun for the first run through of it but then it still seemed bland and not much. Still more time goes by and a new PVP mode and a few updates to co-op and singleplayer, just basically the co-op but a lone. I still had a little bit of hope in this game for a while but right now, three years and nothing to show for and very few to no promises made, I'm starting to struggle even thinking this game will get anywhere, I can't even touch the game anymore, theres nothing. I just comepletely forgot about this game and the company and so did the whole community. The community is lost in their hopes for an amazing co-op and singleplayer game that just probably will never happen. Many of the people who bought this were long fans of the game and thought we were finally going to get what we have been waiting years for. I can't recommend this game to anyone, just not now and the sad truth probably never. It's just an idea left in hiatus. So, don't buy this game. It shouldn't be on steam and its not going anywhere, we never got the co-op or singleplayer we were promised. Just so many PVP updates, it took so long for the first co-op to come in and it was just fighting robots and pressing E on things. Do not get this game, maybe sometime in the future we'll have the game we were promissed and hoped for, but probably not for a long time.If you want this game for PVP it's dead. Completely dead, no one plays anything but around 7 play PVP.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								In it's current state, I DO NOT reccommend this game. However, based on what the devolpers have planned and how frequently the updates are coming along I think it will be a good game in the long run. Let's get to the Pro's and Con's of the game so far. {I PLAN TO UPDATE IT}===PRO===1. The game looks great and runs great, even on some of the lowest settings. The enviroment changes really do add to the combat experience.2. Immersion. The devolpers have been trying to make this game really immersive, and they really have. The rain on the helmet, the ambient sounds, everything about the immersion is great. Once the Oculus Rift support for this game arrives, this will be a MUST-OWN for anyone with an Oculus Rift3. Planned features. This may not seem like a real Pro, but the features the developers want to add sound great. Land Sharks, need I say more? ===CON===1. Only one gun. Gets very boring using the same gun (THOUGH IT IS IN ALPHA, AN EARLY ALPHA). No sidearms, no melee, just your one SMG.2. No hit markers, and the gun feels like it does no damage. Kinda feels like shooting at ghosts until they fall over.3. Only 2 gamemodes (yet again, it's early alpha) Free For All (feels like CoD with one gun) and Team Domination. Team Domination is great mode because it forces teams to work together to hold areas. Sometimes however...4. TEAM KILLING! Your team mates are only marked with little blue lights. Sometimes it can be hard to see if someones on your team, exspecially if they open fire on you.Not gonna rant on how there's no melee or crouching yet in the game, because, once more, it's EARLY ALPHA!In short, Interstellar Marines in it's current state isn't great, but hopefully in a few months it will be well worth the $15.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								How do I think of interstellar marines?This is a good game. That is the easiest way to put it. You get into two team into a battlefield/arena. And similar to counterstrike you have one life. The exception to this one life rule is you can respawn in 200+ seconds or capture a point. The round is usually over in two minutes (with the exception of games that go backwards and forwards) so the only way to really give you team an advantage is to capture the points.What else is great about this game?One of my favourite things about it in the day/night cycles and lighting. Most maps outside have a day and night cycle which changes how you have to play. It's to dark to see anything so you have to use a flashlight but the enemy can pinpoint where you are from the flashlight. You have to play stealthily other wise it's gameover. This goes the same for lazer pointers in daytime. Indoor maps usually have three modes. The light are on normally, There is a red alarm or there are no lights. I find these all brilliant features which change the way you play every now and then.And extra thing that i like about this game!Well the fact the developers put the time and effort into letting you be able to take your mask off is amazing. It is a little feature but it is great fun when a couple of friends and i jump into an empty lobby and take your mask off. It has given us a few laughs like *friendly Fire* and *lucky shots* This game just keeps me coming back for more.The minor thing about this game is the population of it. You will occasionally find a full lobby and a couble of half lobbies but the rest of it is dead. The main reason for that is probably early access and I hope the population grows.(I probably missed some stuff out in this review.. I apologize)In the end I give this game a 9/10 It is great fun. especially with friends!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now you might be thinking to yourself, how can you give this game a positive review already?For many reasons- I had always kept myself on check looking around EVERY corner that i passed.- Had to actually stay with other squad mates to finish the objectives.- Great intro to the game, it just throws you in for your first life. (It is a lot better than it sounds)- Great Co-op experience.- Also, what AAA developers are missing way too much of, seeing your own feet- Sounds are great, but a bit more ambience to levels would be niceThere are a few things that i want added to the game, few of which I am pretty sure that are going to be added to the first place.- Leaning- More weapons and possibly loadout menu- Melee attack of some sort- An actual tutorial (right now it only takes you to a youtube playlist)- More control customizations (Non-Toggle Sprint, one click ADS on/off, hold down click ADS on/off instead of bieng both on at once)- PVP Multiplayer ( I know this is Co-Op but this would be a nice addon to the game, i can see it compete against Insurgency's Multiplayer)- More graphics options- A larger penalty for players for team killingAlthough at the current state (Beta 1.6) this game seems more promising than DAYZ right now. And for this being a Unity game, this looks and feels really nice! I am looking forward towards seeing what else this developing company has to offer!

You would have thought that a bug that makes you unable to fire would have gotten more attention from the developer.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a truly good game.  This is an alpah review as of 09/06/2014 so things will change.  It feels, and I dare say this, like a futuristic cs:source.  The weapons take presicion to handle and it doesn't take more than a couple of well placed rounds to take you out.  The respawn time is punishing, it varies based on how well your team is doing and sometimes you might just have to wait out the round.  The graphics aren't anything crazy, but they look pretty good.  The weather, rain and wind, are amazing!  So are the sounds!  The darkness of the levels is really fun too.  It teaches you to pay attention to where you move.  This game is good.  I hope that it does leave alpha stage and makes some good money because it has so many cool ideas that haven't really been done before.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Quite frankly, I first bought this game after following the updates and I wanted to play it because it added something new to the genre. I played it for a bit with my mate, after getting the spearhead edition for cheap and two keys, we only played multiplayer and was fun for a while. After an hour I got a bit bored becuase it was very slow paced considering the amount of players (4). But with these new updates, I have to say, it might be the best horror experience I've played. It's not intended to be a horror, at least I don't think so, but may I say this game is incredible for that. Playing the neurogen experience for the first time with my friend, we we're both shaking by the end and loved absolutely every second. Hearing a robot in the next room means any loud actions and you're done. The robots spriting at you is incredibly tense and makes me too scared to go around the next corner!!!For a fantastic tactical FPS game with a group of friends, a singleplayer horror experience or a visceral co-op game to hear your friends scream over skype, this game is perfect for you.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is a great game. I'll admit, it's a bit of a rip-off now (they've increase the price by $2 after adding three story missions, 2 new guns, a bunch of other missions and a few new maps) but with the freatures their promising they're basically giving it to you for free. You all have a SMG, Assualt Rifle and Pistol (that looks like some sort of sub-rifle?) with a reflex sight, laser and torch so everything is fairly balanced. The devs are doing really well they have a great community full of people that can help you and make your expeirience as fun as possible although they are very, very, very, very... slow. The single player/co-op that they've added needs some work aswell, it's very shallow and simple. The missions are basically, go to place, kill robots, go to place, kill robots etc. . Some are literally elmination with just robots for you to kill and if your serious about playing this game (as in CSGO mindset serious) they'd be good for practicing on but they're kinda boring. The mulitplayer is whats worth playing. Since there isn't that many people if your not on at peak times you don't play at all and if you have a bad computer/internet you are stuffed. Peak times include: 8:00am -> 12:00am and midnight in Australian time. This is just from my experience and people tend to play more on weekends aswell. Another thing is that I noticed people raged about how defensive the devs are and while I'm guessing their right in my experience (which isn't a terrible amount) the devs have been great. Honestly some of the best indie/early access devs I've worked with excluding big companies (e.g. valve). Hope this updated review is more helpful.This video is what they were up to at the beginning of 2015 i believe: http://steamcommunity.com/app/236370/discussions/0/864978109704524930/P.S. Since when does an Australian get a ping of 40 on Euorpean servers and 300 on Australian servers?

content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								This game delivers one of the most best "tactical" feeling coop experiences out of all the fps game I have played. Sadly the game is on its knees right now and the devs are looking for investors right now to support their game. The shooting feels nice and the atmosphere and locations you are put into are great. It's just that the updates come at a very slow pace and they need to focus more on the coop part of the game not the pvp. There aren't may lvls and the game may keep you entertained up to a few hours. But those hours are amazing indeed. (For me) I'm very sad that this game is on its knees and I'd hate to see this game wither away like this. Is it worth $9.99 ? Yes , and play it with friends but beware that you might only get 10 hrs of play time out of this game. I hope this game gets a full release.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines is a early access game which only has limited multiplayer modes and maps. But it presents what they have in a way that makes it fantastic. The game is going to add a co-op campaign which is bringing inspiration from System Shock. The multiplayer is extremely different to Call of Duty and Battlefield which makes it already a great game. There is lots of recoil and cool tiny things like ligting up your masks for no reason at all. The developers have made it so you can see the outline of the mask over your face. Tiny things like this make the game realistic and makes you feel like you are a marine. There is only one gun which is a assult gun which you can play with at this current time of writing. I hope they add new guns soon to add to the experience. The graphics look amazing for an indie title. Sun glair reflects on your visor aadding to the experience. I would also like to note that Interstellar Marines is harder then it looks. It is extremely hard to kill people and there is a lot of recoil. I would recommend this game to anyone which wants a challenge or is a sci-fi fan such as myself (reminds my of aliens).7.5/10

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								To make it short, just read this review as it's basically how I feel about this game: http://steamcommunity.com/id/bipolar_bear/recommended/236370/I don't know what this game wants to be, nor I care to follow its history and the current discussions as I don't care much about early-access stuff, but I can give you some short details about my own, short, experience with it.To descript it visually, just take the first F.E.A.R., worsen visual quality by reducing models polygon count, quantity and quality of textures, and take out most of its special effects except shadowing. Now reduce framerate by at least 75% and you pretty much have a good idea of how this game looks like.I'm not kidding. I don't know what engine this game uses and how, but even reducing graphics quality to the minimum gives me only like 5fps more than max settings, and I can play any game here, usually at max detail with 16xAF and 4x AA.It's not unplayable but the performance/detail ratio is just terrible right now, so consider that if your system is not very powerful.(EDIT: ok I just checked the game's directory and the game is using Unity. That explains the terrible performance and will also give you a good insight of what you can expect from this game in the future: a lot of troubles.)The game starts with a tutorial. It all goes well though it's pretty tedious, but I've seen worse. The real problem starts with the campaign. I'm not really into tactical shooters and I don't even see anything that tactical in this game, I just know that there's no save button that I can find and the enemy can take you down in just 2 shots, and that happens more often than just taking 1 single shot. With that I mean that you often die by what seem to be just a single bullet but I learned that it's actually 2 shots in rapid succession: the first takes out your armor completely (it will auto regenerate after a lot of seconds) and the second will kill you.Ok I'm probably too much into Rambo-style games, where you just rush into packs of enemies at once, but that's just silly. I would have enjoyed it a bit more if it weren't for that, but after dying a couple times I decided it was time to move on and try the coop.I don't like versus games, so I just wanted to test the coop mode. Despite of me choosing coop from the menu, I was presented by a big server list of on-going games, which keeps updating making it hard to pick the one you need (at least if you sort them by ping, as I usually do). It becomes a FPS game into a FPS game to aim and shoot the join button of the right server you want to join in less than a second, but I'm sure that situation will get better after the free week.The real problem is that this list also had versus games, which I accidentally joined. I then realized my mistake (I was attracted by the high player count), got killed in the usual 2-shots-that-looked-like-1 and then left it.I then joined a real coop game and the situation didn't get better, but actually worse.People kept joining and then leaving after 10 minutes of going around pointlessly, looking for whatever the game wanted us to look for, with no sight of enemies, unpickable cards (they were maybe audiologs but I don't know, they just looked like keycards to me), closed doors and out-of-map fun, but yeah, that gets old soon.I tried a couple more games but one ended seconds after I joined, with the usual mass player leave after it, and the other had a mass leave before it ended, so I was left alone with not much to do.It all looks very early, very simple, already seen, bland.I'm not sure for how long the developers has been working on this, but considering what I saw, the road ahead is very long still. So long that it looks almost endless considering how much work this game seem to need before becoming interesting, at least for me.From my very little experience, it seem that the only thing this game has to offer right now is a versus mode that seem to work, though I didn't really look so much into it because of the reasons above.Not my kind of game right now, but I hope one day it'll get finished, and then I'll happily take another look at it.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I did not put many hours (yet), but still, here comes my review.Facts:SP/MP first person shooter.Long times between updates. Some says, game is in developer hell.Well, i quite disagree. Yes, update rate is very slow, but when they deliver content, it's rock solid and stable.I admitt ,i did not followed every single update, but when i come back from time to time, there are ALWAYS improvements and something new.I rather give them time and enjoy game than to be excited about 3 updates in month and find out, subsequent updates just fix what previous updates broke.AAA games might envy. For example, BF4 bad start and updates two steps up, one back.Personal experience.Now it's great game.What i like is constantly changing environment and weather. Very refreshing. Stands out from other online fps.Fun fact:Some years ago i was frustrated with team balance and did some teamkill(s). Nothing big but not innocent. Six month later when new update arrived i found, i got banned from MP.(hehe)Contacted devs, explained, apologized and got unban.Conclusion: Devs are normal people.Devs actually care for community of their game.Be good guy, and dont TK. :)One thing: Even now, when there is a lot of single player content, i recently found a nice feature: in game press F1, online chat will open and you can invite other atm online players to match. :)Many times in past i wanted to play, but when i checked MP maps, no one was there. :/ So we DO have option to gather players :)No player dedicated servers = one authority = no badmins (u keep killing me all time i ban u from my celeron attic server) = no playerbase splitSingle player missions -> great!Intense hunting (or being hunted?)Outnumbered but not outpalyed :)Cheaters? I dont think i met one.Cons:Maybe it's me, but to my taste there are a lot of places where you get temporaly blocked when moving.Like you want to go upstairs and you approach like  in 99% of other online fps games but boom, you stuck and you just HAVE TO move that 10cm more to continue your walk. I would be happy if characters have freedom(style) of moving like in CoD2(2005) or Quake. I'm not talking about speed, i talk about that feeling of moving freedom. Here, when i'm moving i have to focus all time to not get stuck. That's biggest con to me. Make moving system more benevolent to environment?Ai in lower difficulties can get stuck in doors or railing.(didn't try highest difficulty yet)So better AI path finding is needed. Or don't improve them too much? Still 1 vs 38 terminators! Just kidding, i'm best under pressure :) Or you are behind some cube and your gun barrel goes up because it's realistic. FFS i want to be ready to shot 100% of time when i want to shot. This propably ain't gonna change.More palyers :)  Hey just use F1 and you get your match :) Faster updates? I don't know, game is in ok state now. IMO except movement style. I repeat, i don't have high number of hours.==========================Game was/is worth my time.
