content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is still a bit crude (early access), but it has the beginnings of a great tactical shooter and it does get updated with a modicum of new content about once in a month. It already has a good amount of gamemodes, both co-op and versus. The gunplay is good and smooth and everything feels properly balanced even at the early-access stage. They've really put some effort into the details and the sci-fi athmosphere, which I have to like. Detracting is the lack of enemy, gun and gadget variety (most enemies are just the basic robotic dummies that either attack bare-handed or with guns, and you only have 2 guns at this point that you can equip with silencers and laser sights).One thing I didn't like is that there is no way to host your own dedicated server if you wanted to play with your friends for example. Thus you have little control over the multiplayer component (though you can join a game and set it to friends-only, but you still don't have much control over what maps or modes are being played). There are some glitches, such as revive not working always, and buggy enemy spawns and pathfinding, but they don't happen everytime.Still, it is showing a lot of promise. They update regularly and there is a playerbase in the multiplayer. I will try to keep posted on it and I hope that at some point we will be able to host our own games so we have some control over what we play.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Be aware this game is early alpha, and thus I'm reviewing my impressions on the game as of November 8, 2014.)Interstellar Marines is a Co-Op Tactical FPS. It pits you and 3 other teammates who are, you guess it, interstellar marines, against defective robots in a battle to survive to the end by means of elimination, escaping, or simply surviving. Or, you can also go against other players in a control point-style battle.This game actually has a good amount of realism and atmosphere which blend very well for a game like this. The game has a real dark atmosphere to it, feels genuinely creepy and lonely with only your friends by your side. The maps, for the most part, are like an abandoned and broken facility. Very dark, and your main light source would be flickering lights or your own flashlight. It really brings immersion into the game, which is very helpful. The animations of the marines too are very well done, especially in first person. You actually see your arms move as you look around, see your own feet, and so on. Small detail, but very welcome.Speaking of realism, that's one of the best parts of the game. Whenever you take damage, your hearing is impaired (which is important in this game), your HUD disappears until you heal, and team damage/killing is also real. The guns aren't all that powerful either, but that's a good thing. The robots you face are very powerful, and can down you in seconds. You only have two guns: One for short range, and one for long range. Neither have that much ammo in it's clip (Probably enough for 3-4 robots if you're accurate), or have amazing accuracy, so you need to be precise and careful; Spraying and gunning your way through just won't succeed.Teamwork is heavily emphasized here. It's only four of you, and because the robots are so powerful, you're likely to go down. The only way you can survive is if your teammates revive you in your 15 seconds of last breaths. The aforementioned guns are weak with only one person, so if hoards of robots come, you all need to use your ammo and shoot tactically.There's currently 5 game modes as of this review, and they all have nice variety to the game. Elimination is killing all the robots in the area, Escape is moving to the top of the facility while surviving from the bots, Survivial is activiating several objectives and then escaping (with robots.), and Stronghold is the PvP game mode, 2 teams trying to capture all points in the area. The other mode is a campaign mission, titled The Neurogen Incident. It appears to be story oriented, but I cannot currently play it as it crashes my game.All in all, Marines is an incredible team based tactical shooter, especially for being early access! And I would really recommend this to anybody who wants some good times with their friends, using teamwork to achieve the goal in a dark and desolate enviornment.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros:Very promising for an Alpha, one of the most polished I've seen in a while. The development process is made in to a 'storyline' it would seem, where the marines are currently doing a number of training scenarios. Future updates propose team based PvE combat against an unknown enemy as of yet(?) I haven't done that much digging in to exactly what is planned, but apparently it is the basis for the game. The PvP is fantastic, smooth and responsive. The level design is incredibly innovative and it will keep you interested throughout the entire round. Some levels will have the physical properties changed during stages of the round (doors/ramps being blocked or parts of the map moving up and down), and simulation of fire drills/power outages putting you in complete darkness and forcing you to change tactics.Cons:Server hosting issues where all across NA you will ping around 100 to the server, personally I ping 125-150 to every NA server despite this not being an issue anywhere else. This leads to a 1/4-1/2 second bullet delay, requiring you to lead moving targets slightly regardless of distance from you. This is also combined with a very small hit detection issue. Overall, the problem is minor for an Alpha considering it is the only apparent problem I've seen yet, and loving every second of the game otherwise.The game is worth $15.00, so it's absolutely worth it for you to grab it at 7.50 on one of the sales or even pick up the more expensive version and score a free copy for a friend + some exclusive titles for you being a founder.Get this game, help it to grow and become amazing!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even though I just recieved this game, I can already tell it will be great. This game is an epic mix of space and first person shooter, allowing you to feel like an Interstellar Marine while gunning down the enemy. After getting a hang of the controls and learning how to get the perfect shots in, you can really begin to appreciate just what went into this game. The graphics aren't the Battlefield 4 good, but they are pretty darn good, and add this in to the ever changing environment, (which is also amazing), and you get an enjoyable game not only from the firefights, but the visuals too.                                                                              Pros- Good graphics, enjoyable gameplay, and an epic feel.Cons- Still early access meaning that many features aren't available, like more multiplayer options, singleplayer, and a few bugs every now and again, and it could be smoothed out.Over all I think that this is a great game that you will have hours of fun in. A few things I would like to see in the final build are better movement, (feels kinda slow), also feels like the bullets travel slowly in CQB, but mostly just some smoothing and customizability options, which they are working on. All I can say if you are thinking about buying this is go ahead and buy it while it's on sale! It will only get more expensive as they finish it!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
INTERSTELLAR MARINES: MINI REVIEW AND FIRST IMPRESSIONSThis game.. This game is something new. I've only scratched the surface on what's to come, but here's my minor review, good, bad and would it be worth getting? THE GOOD:Is heavily reliant on hyper-realism, and does a good job with audio and over-all feel with the game.Great graphics, and doesn't take much HDD space (Max 2GB, base game is only 1GB).Neatly optimized.Great community against new players.Solo-campaign.PvP is engaging in innovative strategizing methods. The floors move, the lights go out, anything can happen.PvP is heavily teamwork reliant to win a match.PvE is still buggy, but relies on thinking about what way you want to approach your objectives. Go all-out brute or stealth-only? You, and your team's choice, really. THE BAD:Could use more maps.Could use more game-modes for both PvE and PvP, especially PvP suffers from the same game-mode, although fun as it is.Trolls (by teamkilling and trashtalking in chat), although not that many, really, could be combatted by votekicking.Could use more weapons. (Although I know that it will eventually be implemented soon.) THE VERDICT:9/10, Would buy.As the game is still in early stages, I will still hold my finger on the trigger and keep an eye on this title.Still much to be implemented, still much to discuss.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Currently early access beta, Interstellar Marines is a tactical FPS that is beautiful, balanced, screaming potential, squirting loads of fun, innovative, a catching story, and waiting hundreds of hours of gameplay. With it being in beta it has many surprises to come. I.M. is something that will tickle your fancy if you were ever into the Halo: Combat Evolved and/or Counter-Strike scene. The multiplayer gameplay is dynamic, fast paced, fun, and strongly teamwork oriented. While playing not only are you presented with hostile forces like sharks walking on land lunging at you, but you have to adapt to environmental conditions, as well. While it is raining water will bead up on your helmet's visor hindering your sight some, you can open your helmet like the bill of a ball cap to improve your vision. Opening your visor will also help improve vision while taking damage, however, your visor will display information. There may be other uses for the visor to come as the updates are released like enviornmental hazards. Know your situation and prepare! It's a fantastic game and I'd like to see more people playing!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is nowhere near finished but that doesn't stop it being alot of fun. The levels are well designed and the models look good. There is a solid multiplayer experience already where you have to to capture and hold points on the map. The environmental effects really change the gameplay. Sometimes the level goes dark and you will need your flashlight to see properly, but you may not want to because that could expose your position to enemies. Similarly your gun has a laser that you can turn on and off, which helps you improve your aim but also can give away your position, as the laser is also visible to enemies. Had a blast playing this so far and I can't wait for more weapons and features to arrive. Funner than Counter-Strike (and i like counter-strike)For all you potential Australian buyers: yes there is a healthy Australian server. And of course servers in the US and EU.

								Check back and... yeah[+] How the helmet works was kinda good, player can open and close the front helmet. When closed player can track any necessary combat information, but when opened player can remove that pesky water effect in raining map and shiny light effect in return can not track any combat information.[+] I can see my legs, ahahahaha.[-] Spiky lag...[-] Current campaign feel bland... you spawned on kinda small map, got mission info from AI? to do this, do that, inform this and that.... thats it all? no cul cut-scene or event? you bye-cha... kiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiin!Something to note :Misc :[] No game updates since March 2016.[] At May 2016 the dev announced about expanding to PS4 and XBox One... godamit, just complete the current PC version first![] If you lured by that cool shark-mutant enemy ... then, no, they are still not in the game.[] Only 2 missions for coop and campaign... +1 tutorial mission, but... for me it is puking boring... your only opponents is robot (the same puking model)... at first was ok but getting annoyed with the sounds fx...  [] Online coop mode, got 2 EU server and 4 US-West server, but... 0/4... dead (well atleast when I checked it per 17-11-2016)[] Online mp mode, few server and yeah 0/18... dead, same date as above.[] Online wargame mode, ... 1 server? but no info how many players inside? try to join, got only my name on the list, yeah dead.[] From last play (means long ago lol) Drop-in in coop will spawn from the first spawner.... kinda wasting time for looking other players "guys! where are you?" .... "Timun Emas! arek ayu?!"[] There is sandbox (playing around in current sp and mp map alone) and challenges but ... well I buy and support this at first was for sp campaign and online coop.... so... meh.Weaponry :[] only 3 guns?, smg and 2 rifle?... with toggle-able silencer, laser sight.... tazer ammo type... errr thats all?Map level :[] Infiltration mission.... errr .... okay noone around, crouching tiger sloooowwly... krik... krikk... krikkkk.... MAOOOoooooooooo (robot sounds fx) .... blepblepblepblepblepblepblep (gun fires as my helmet system go down).... yeah its just I cant feel the vibe of being space marine doing infiltration mission...[] Retrieval mission.... same as above... godamit robot! MAOOOoooooooooo ... blepblepblepblepblepblepblep... Currently I can't say like it or not... but yeah for sure not recommended with current state... sorry :(

Early Access Review
								0_0 Interstellar Marines is intense!!! the first mission which is just a training mission basically where you learn controls and what not, sets up the story and puts you right into the action... If you want to call it that. The action is very subtle and when it happens it is scary intense. The causing factors are the anticipation, the ambiance, the narrator, the enemies intelligence, even the training mission captures all these!! Along the way to the first mission, the narrator gives you simple instructions and it is your job to get it done. What makes it scary is certain warnings she might give about the enemies and trust her, the robots will sneak up on you and kill you in game, but also in real life by giving you a heart attack!!Only having played the training and part of level two single player, I can tell this will be a perfect unintentional-horror, stealth, puzzle, first person shooter game when it is finished. Puzzle? you may ask. for each objective, there are many ways to achive this. Go stealthy or guns blazing, but don't forget to relode or you will die!! What a must have video game!!

Early Access Review
								Is it done? no. Does it develope quickly? no. Apparently there's only one guy still actively developing it. But that doesnt matter. Look, right now its on sale for FIVE DOLLARS. Otherwise, it's only TEN. The game, finished or not, has more than enough gameplay in it already to justify the cost in the state that it is in now. Unfinished means nothing, it's just people whining in the review section. Value means something, not some superficial status. And this game has more than five dollars of value. Anything added is a bonus in my eyes. The game is incredibly atmospheric, terrifying at times when its you and one or two of your friends in a dimly lit spaceshit or station as you hear the loud metallic footsteps of unseen enemies, creep around the corners slowly and carefully, just to catch a bullet to the side of the face and jump out of your skin. this is a game for people who like atmosphere, plain and simple. if you want some epic action packed space marine game, dont bother, its not for you. its not intended for you. you wont enjoy.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I picked up this game early on in it's release. I was sold by the (seeming) progress that had been made when it went EA, The compelling dev interviews, the pretty strong stylised aesthetic and the promise of Rainbow 6/System Shock in space. It did not seem like a tall order at all. The concepts were there and the game already had a lot of cool ideas implemented. Put in the ideas, polish the rough edges and we would have had a winner. A few months later and it then seemed the devs wanted to turn it into a strong multi player focused game which was not what I wanted, but the devs said that they would build up the player base and use the MP to balance the game and tweak single player. Ok, sure.  The audience wanted to help the devs achieve that premise through feedback and support. This game generated a lot of hype and people trying to build a community they imagined would exist and grow like the Arma and Rainbow 6 crowds. Fanart and groups were created. A year later and I am fighting stupid cannon fodder super accurate robots with the same weak feeling weapons and it feels like a multi-player game with a tacked on single player rather than this amazing single player campaign we had been sold. Incredibly shoddy AI and zero noticable improvement. It was pure lip service paid to the original premise on which the game was pitched.Here we are another year later and it looks like the game is going to be dropped. There is practically no hope for a fraction of what was promised and the worst part was that it was not an insurmountable task. They had a neat framework to hang some great original gameplay and ideas and they did not even come close to trying to be as innovative as they originally seemed to intend. The game will go on that long list of black listed steam games that are remembered not for even being failures, but for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ behaviour and cowardice of the dev team. They did not fail because they never really tried. If it wasn't for games like Prison Architect, Satellite Reign and Nuclear Throne, I would never bother with EA. The only reason this game is still in my library is the fact the devs are teaming up with a publisher. In a year's time this review may be completely wrong and I get to eat my words with a big spoon. I doubt it, but I hope so.Edit: I just checked back in to see if there was any progress with the game. (There is not)I noticed that the price is about half what I paid. Now the general idea of some early access games is you pay less now so the devs have the capital to make the game. This rule is by no means applied across the board. But it's a kick to the teeth when when you paid twice as much for an early access game than people jumping on board now, knowing it's dead in the water. But then again, thats EA and half of nothing is still nothing. This game is dead. The devs should have the decency to announce it and bury it.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								i have had this game since it has been out and the support is barely even there, if at all. For example, they started out with two guns; a assualt rifle and a marksman-like rifle. Fine. In the 3 years this has been out they added one gun. A dinky machine pistol. I feel bad because i bought this game formy friends as well and it has just been collecting dust in their library. We can't refund it because while we have definitley played less than 8 hours of the game, we have owned it for more than two weeks. This is the type of game that weakens people's belief in the early access concept. You get people excited by saying that this is a return to form for the FPS at a time where FPS games a getting stagnant, then you have a proof of concept by having a working build that shows promise, then do absolutely nothing substatial with it for 3 years except for multiplayer and a sparse campaign that explains nothing and has no cohesion as a narritive whatsoever. I saw something good in this game, but as of now and for the last 2 years, i cannot reccomend this game. No support, barely any content, and lacking alot of what was promised 3 years ago. Your money is well spent elsewhere. And be wary of early access. It's not all bad, but there are people out there willing to abuse the system; like making a promising game, getting a bunch of people to invest early thinking it will be something, then disappearing with all that money.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Want to sneak through dark buildings and shoot down armies of trigger happy (not to mention creepy) training robots? Join a handful of interstellar marines as they skirmish in intense fire fights against their own comrads? Or even travel across beautiful underground landscapes in search of loot, waiting to engage a fellow wandering marine around every corner? Sir, you have come to the right game. Interstellar Marines is one of the most emersive shooters you will find, anywhere. Sporting some outstanding gun mechanics, dynamic enviorments (by dynamic, I mean that sections of the maps actually shift and move), and a hunger game-like game mode... Underground! AS AN INTSTELLAR MARINE!!! Seriously, who doesn't want to be a special ops solder from the future!? Anyway, this is pretty much the only game I play now, and I highly suggest it. Double thumbs up.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very impressed for an early access. I've had it for a while, and, though I haven't played it much, I really like it. I didn't get around to playing Neurogen Incident until today, and was quite satisfied. Borrows the feelings of solitude and the quietness in outer space from Dead Space, but instead of limb-slashing necromorphs, so far the only enemies are robots (though we're all waiting for the landshark!), with one kind that charges at you and beats you, and another wielding guns. While there is no goriness so far, the robots' eerie robotic screaming and oinking (sounds like it) make them quite creepy, especially when you hear them screaming right before charging at you out of nowhere! The lack of checkpoints and pausing can either add to the tension, or be an inconvenience, depending on how you want to look at it. Multiplayer is aight. The changing of lighting/artificial weather are cool, but don't make up for the flatness of TDM. Once again, this is just an early access, and judging by how updates have been going, this game will become freaking amazing. I'd definitely recommend buying, even at its current early stages.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines is a highly ambitious tactical FPS, promising a unique co-op experience with roleplaying and nonlinear gameplay. According to the developers, the game is heavily influenced by the likes of Half Life, System Shock 2 and Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield and will have a heavy focus on realistic science fiction. Interstellar Marines has been in ongoing development for a very long time and the team have been subjected to quite a few complications. Zero Point Software has had to overcome some obstacles along the way, such as having to change game engine mid-development, filing for bankruptcy, as well as failing to reach their Kickstarter Campaign goal of $600,000.At the time of the publication of this review, Interstellar Marines is in Steam Early Access and is expecting full release in late 2014. The game currently consists only of a multiplayer component, featuring the 'Team Domination' game mode, where the objective is to capture and hold areas within the map to gain points. All of the maps in the game feature a dynamic environment with changing lightning and weather conditions. This is for me the only real differentiator between Interstellar Marines and other FPS games at the moment. The dynamic environment force players to change their play style multiple times throughout the match. One moment, the map might be well lit and players will sprint to the objectives playing very offensively, until suddenly, the map goes completely dark and people will move slowly around using their flashlight sparsely to avoid detection. These sudden changes in player mentality really helps the game in terms of its tactical focus.While Interstellar Marines' tactical aspect is quite impressive, it still has some fairly major shortcomings. Firstly, the game has yet to receive basic FPS functionality such as crouching and proper sprinting which is kind of odd, considering its long development. The shooting and overall gameplay is extremely barebones and not very satisfying. The assets of the game are fairly limited, and many of the maps are littered with big identical boxes at every corner. Lastly, the game has a very lackluster options menu, with barely any settings at all. Brightness and gamma sliders are not available at current time, which unfortunately for me means that under medium-low light situations my monitor looks absolutely horrible. This might just be a problem I am having, but settings like these should be fairly standard anyway.All of this can of course be improved as time goes on, considering it's still in Early Access, but I do have my worries as the game is expected to release later this year. The game seems like it's been stuck in progress in the 1,5 years I've been following it, which honestly make me speculate if this game is vaporware. ZP Software is currently promising a fully fletched story campaign with up to 4 player co-op, roleplaying elements, an open game world, and a customizable arsenal. As you might see, this is a lot of content, of which none exist as of yet. Taking into account that Zero Point Software are a very small development team, it is quite hard to figure out just exactly how they will manage to put out so much content in just under a year.Whether my speculations are unfound, and the game will end up getting a successful release or not, is up to Zero Point Software. But as it stands, I do have my doubts and will therefore recommend waiting for the game to receive more content before buying into it.

Early Access Review
								The map loads as my visor slides down over my face and I attach a silencer to my sub-machine gun, and then my rifle as the gates to hell unfold. I willingly step through them and am thrust into a dark enviornment with lethal robots. Fast foward 5 minutes, and I've killed 10 out of seemingly countless robots, although there are only 40. Enter Interstellar Marines, an amazingly intense shooter. These past few updates have made the game worth playing, because, beforehand, the multiplayer was often empty. content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far, Interstellar Marines seems like a great game in the making, but the 15$ price seems like a bit much, since until today no one's been on the multiplayer servers, so it's just been finding all the cool little parts of the maps. With update 11 (which was released today and is probably the only reason someone's actually on the server.) They've bumped the price up to 18$, which I'm guessing is for the new gamemode. However, in its current state, I'm thinking more like 8$ would be a good price. However, if they don't bump up the price every once in a while, the creators will run out of funds to continue developing the game. It seems like they've got most of the basic mechanics down (Which so far are pretty good, just need to add the campaign/NPCs and maybe promote the multiplayer servers a bit more). So as long as it keeps updating (which seems promising) and the final product has the co-op campaign they promised, I'll feel that my money was well-spent. Keep it up, Zero Point Software, and good luck! :D

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is a bit early to write a reveiw about this game, due to it being in Early Access. Still, for being in Early Access I think it's a great game to play! I feel the game excells when playing with other people online, due to the freakish way the game is played; in a good way. There are both pros and cons to this game, as I will list a few of them below.Pros:- Simpy frightful! You'll find as you play that you have no idea what to expect. Robots seem to come out of no where, which can really creap you out; and with little, it's hard to see them from a distance.- Almost realiztic! You notice quickly that there's no aiming assisant, which I think makes the game a lot more fun to play. There is a Red Dot Sight, as well scoping which will help you to aim.- Anothing amising thing which I enjoy is your amount of health! Every player has so little that 2 bullets, or melee attacks will kill you, making it seem a lot more relizticCons:- The option to paly survivle doesn't seem like survivle. The goal of survivle is to "servive" for as long as you can or for a certain amount of time. Here they have you complete objectives instead of surviving.Multiplayer is also a blast and fun to play. Just be careful, you only have one life!Interstellar Marines9/10Can't wait to see what else they add and fix to the game!

								Actually, surprisingly, a very solid shooter with tight mechanics and very, very good optimisation.Only con would be not enough content or weapons right now, but if they make all the weapons feel as nice as the two they have, it will be amazing.Levels load in seconds for me... Literally, a few seconds. Constant framerate of 75 (even though one of my cards is dead right now thats on par with CS with two cards, and looks better) If the server has good ping, the shot recognition feels VERY good, theres no kill cam so I cant call "BS" on any kills but I didnt feel cheated at all (LIke i do in CSGO when i run around a corner but the 64tick server still thinks im out of cover, or my shots miss if i'm on the other end) Definitely worth keeping an eye on if not buying. At its sale price right now of 7 bucks, its a steal, full price at 20 bucks, good value even in its current state (Two weapons, but lots of maps and AI survival modes)I say this not because it shows promise, but because it has delivered. as of right now you have a tactical team-based shooter with some cool mechanics (Like respawning on a cap) some serious immersion, and great tactical shooter moments.... seeing how i got duped and paid $100 for the broken shooter that was battlefield 4, this is worth every penny

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay let me just say this game does what few games actually do. Scare me. Sure other games can give you a couple jumpscares but all the horror levels I have playedd are permadeath. No respawn. You learn to fear for your life in game more and more the farther you get. Your character is also not too tanky so a couple of hits and your deadI give this game and 8/10 currently as there are still some issues such as slightly buggy stairs and the Ai sometimes gets caught on small things. Overall though considering its still in alpha my expectations for this game is a 9.5-10/10 when all is said and done. Graphics are quite good. Another minor negitive is there are only 2 weapons both of which are auto fire. I may just have failed to discover how but if there were ways to change from auto to burst or semi firing on the rifle that would improve the gameplay significantly in my opinion.To rate my experience for this alpha though 10/10 would weep like a little girl in a corner again

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								A good game overal with the gameplay, but when it comes down to the rest of teh game it can at times fall short.The game is somewhat based on a futureish time frame, so I would expect to see more tech than just a cool HUD and robots...What the game lacks in graphics it makes up for in diffictulty. When I started playing I expected it to be slightly harder than any other shooter (thus the MARINES in the name) but, I would have to say that the normal mode was a bit too "hard".I say "hard" because the game itself wasn't difficult, the robo-guards were just inacurate yet when they hit you you were basically dead. There were several occasions where I was simply walking around and a guard randomly saw me across the map and killed me in two hits. So overall I would recommend this game, it was a lot of fun, it just needs a little touching up and more futuristic gear (If that is the feel the developers are going for)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok, first off, you die WAY too fast. Second off, people are idiots and never revive you. Third off, the tutorial is literally worthless.Movement seems incredibly clunky and stealth is a worthless mechanic in this game. Don't use it.Yeah, I've only played about an hour of the game, but if I can't move past one hour because of these glaring issues, we're going to need to have a heart to heart, you know?So, there's literally no explination to how the mechanics work. In every other FPS it's either so simple only an idiot wouldn't understand it, or there is an extentive, scaling campain which teaches you how to play the game.No no, in this game I have no idea how to do half the crap in it, and the missions are worthless wastes of time.Did I mention the control layout?Press shift to switch between 'jog' and 'walk' and hold shift to run. F is for flash light, which is understandable. G is for the laser, which is OK because there are no grenades.Did I mention there's also no mele? Yep, you have to spray n' pray at close range. Oh yeah, there's no reticle to help in that regard, either.Oh yeah, and there's no surround sound. Someone can be on the right of you, but the noise is coming out of both speakers. So have fun trying to pinpoint where people are based on sound.I understand this is a small dev team, but there needs to be some serious work put into this game before it's even worthy to be mentioned anywhere but here. On steam.I'll try to mention anything gamebreaking that I come across, but that seems to be the high point of this game....There are no bugs. For an early access game, this is practically bugless.My advice to the dev team? Bring this game over to Bethesda and have them produce the bulk content. Then you guys can make it bugless. It would literally be a perfect game with no issues that everyone would love no matter why they play the game.So, here's the TL;DR: It will need a lot of work in the gameplay, audio, and content department. This is a given for an early access game, and I'm not telling you to forget this game forever. I'm telling you to wait a while to see what happens.All in all? It feels like it's trying to imulate Payday 2 type stealth, but without any real knowldge how.On the "This game has the potential to be awesome" scale: 9/10On the "Current rating of the game" scale: 2/10INVEST WITH CARE.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Backed this game before it was on steam. It was the first game I was truly excited for. But the focus on multiplayer has caused the decs to stray away from their original plans, which was a tactical and strategic singleplayer sci-fi shooter. don't get me wrong, multiplayer is a good thing, but if the primary focus was a singleplayer experience, the focus should not have been on multiplayer so much. Yes it's nice to have something to play, but more should have been turned towards the fundamentals of the game. The couple of missions available are a great teaser to see what this game could have been like, but after a couple playthroughs, they get old quick. I hope they find a publisher or an investor and make the game they wanted, but until then, there is not much point to playing this game. I wish I could say otherwise. I am truly disappointed.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
Early Access Review
								I absolutly loved Interstellar Marines before the Early Access Update #2 arrived.  Everything about the game was perfect!  Now, the game is in Update #8 and I don't like it anymore.  Most if not all the things I loved about the game have changed.  The game mechanics need a lot of work, (Aiming, gun shot recoil, taking damage).  The developers are too focused on aesthetics like being able to take off your mask or how the screen bobbles up and down as you walk or run.  I've experienced the game when it was fantastic, (before update #2) and when it wasn't so great, (after update #2).  The original gameplay of Interstellar Marines is what keeps me looking back at this game.  If it never becomes what it once was, I will not be playing this when it is released.  I will recommend this game (only if) the developers get it together and work on the basics. It was 5/5 stars but now it's 2/5 stars in my book.  I WANT MY INTERSTELLAR MARINES BACK :'(Now to change course a little bit, I do recommend going here http://www.interstellarmarines.com/ to see what the developers have in mind for the final stage of the game. This link will take you to their home page where you can play the game in a more accurate setting.  These games are web-browser based.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Personally, for an early access game, it's fairly engaging. However, pros and cons do exist here, and I do feel they should be addressed.Pros:1) GREAT atmosphere. Personally choosing which directions to go, what weapons to have out, and what to do seemed more than filled with it's fair share of tension on a solo mission. You know the enemy is dangerous, and taking it out quickly is essential as they can more than easily take you down with their bonzai-like charges or sudden gunfire in your direction. Even frightening at some parts for me, though not too much.2) Lovely graphics. Personally I was impressed with the graphics and how realistic they made everything seem.3) From my experience, the community is decent. The first time I ever played a multiplayer server, I actually got great people. They were friends, and we all used teamwork to get past difficult objectives. They were friendly to the new players and happy to lend out a hand.Cons:1) Lack of community. Out of a good number of 10-15 servers (Give or take a few), usually only 2-4 of these have players in them at any given time. Admittedly very annoying.2) Only two weapons? I was hoping for a bit more weapon diversity, as though the two weapons obviously serve different purposes, their usefulness in close quarters combat against these bonzai charging robots can be panic filled when they close in. Not too annoying when your comrades can simply press 'E' to instantly revive you, but when players are fairly close together, this can lead to disaster.3) Lag. Admittedly my computer is not exactly a gaming device that's beefed up or such. But even when attempting my best to lower graphics options (Which was also nearly useless) I felt that on larger maps my progress was slowed down to a nearly unplayable rate as my FPS dropped to an average of about 15. Bleh.Obviously not the perfect review, but if the lack of players doesn't turn you off and your computer is better than some windows 8 laptop, go ahead! This game is well worth the buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Actually, surprisingly, a very solid shooter with tight mechanics and very, very good optimisation.Only con would be not enough content or weapons right now, but if they make all the weapons feel as nice as the two they have, it will be amazing.Levels load in seconds for me... Literally, a few seconds. Constant framerate of 75 (even though one of my cards is dead right now thats on par with CS with two cards, and looks better) If the server has good ping, the shot recognition feels VERY good, theres no kill cam so I cant call "BS" on any kills but I didnt feel cheated at all (LIke i do in CSGO when i run around a corner but the 64tick server still thinks im out of cover, or my shots miss if i'm on the other end) Definitely worth keeping an eye on if not buying. At its sale price right now of 7 bucks, its a steal, full price at 20 bucks, good value even in its current state (Two weapons, but lots of maps and AI survival modes)I say this not because it shows promise, but because it has delivered. as of right now you have a tactical team-based shooter with some cool mechanics (Like respawning on a cap) some serious immersion, and great tactical shooter moments.... seeing how i got duped and paid $100 for the broken shooter that was battlefield 4, this is worth every penny

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay let me just say this game does what few games actually do. Scare me. Sure other games can give you a couple jumpscares but all the horror levels I have playedd are permadeath. No respawn. You learn to fear for your life in game more and more the farther you get. Your character is also not too tanky so a couple of hits and your deadI give this game and 8/10 currently as there are still some issues such as slightly buggy stairs and the Ai sometimes gets caught on small things. Overall though considering its still in alpha my expectations for this game is a 9.5-10/10 when all is said and done. Graphics are quite good. Another minor negitive is there are only 2 weapons both of which are auto fire. I may just have failed to discover how but if there were ways to change from auto to burst or semi firing on the rifle that would improve the gameplay significantly in my opinion.To rate my experience for this alpha though 10/10 would weep like a little girl in a corner again

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								A good game overal with the gameplay, but when it comes down to the rest of teh game it can at times fall short.The game is somewhat based on a futureish time frame, so I would expect to see more tech than just a cool HUD and robots...What the game lacks in graphics it makes up for in diffictulty. When I started playing I expected it to be slightly harder than any other shooter (thus the MARINES in the name) but, I would have to say that the normal mode was a bit too "hard".I say "hard" because the game itself wasn't difficult, the robo-guards were just inacurate yet when they hit you you were basically dead. There were several occasions where I was simply walking around and a guard randomly saw me across the map and killed me in two hits. So overall I would recommend this game, it was a lot of fun, it just needs a little touching up and more futuristic gear (If that is the feel the developers are going for)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								It is a bit early to write a reveiw about this game, due to it being in Early Access. Still, for being in Early Access I think it's a great game to play! I feel the game excells when playing with other people online, due to the freakish way the game is played; in a good way. There are both pros and cons to this game, as I will list a few of them below.Pros:- Simpy frightful! You'll find as you play that you have no idea what to expect. Robots seem to come out of no where, which can really creap you out; and with little, it's hard to see them from a distance.- Almost realiztic! You notice quickly that there's no aiming assisant, which I think makes the game a lot more fun to play. There is a Red Dot Sight, as well scoping which will help you to aim.- Anothing amising thing which I enjoy is your amount of health! Every player has so little that 2 bullets, or melee attacks will kill you, making it seem a lot more relizticCons:- The option to paly survivle doesn't seem like survivle. The goal of survivle is to "servive" for as long as you can or for a certain amount of time. Here they have you complete objectives instead of surviving.Multiplayer is also a blast and fun to play. Just be careful, you only have one life!Interstellar Marines9/10Can't wait to see what else they add and fix to the game!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Backed this game before it was on steam. It was the first game I was truly excited for. But the focus on multiplayer has caused the decs to stray away from their original plans, which was a tactical and strategic singleplayer sci-fi shooter. don't get me wrong, multiplayer is a good thing, but if the primary focus was a singleplayer experience, the focus should not have been on multiplayer so much. Yes it's nice to have something to play, but more should have been turned towards the fundamentals of the game. The couple of missions available are a great teaser to see what this game could have been like, but after a couple playthroughs, they get old quick. I hope they find a publisher or an investor and make the game they wanted, but until then, there is not much point to playing this game. I wish I could say otherwise. I am truly disappointed.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
Early Access Review
								I absolutly loved Interstellar Marines before the Early Access Update #2 arrived.  Everything about the game was perfect!  Now, the game is in Update #8 and I don't like it anymore.  Most if not all the things I loved about the game have changed.  The game mechanics need a lot of work, (Aiming, gun shot recoil, taking damage).  The developers are too focused on aesthetics like being able to take off your mask or how the screen bobbles up and down as you walk or run.  I've experienced the game when it was fantastic, (before update #2) and when it wasn't so great, (after update #2).  The original gameplay of Interstellar Marines is what keeps me looking back at this game.  If it never becomes what it once was, I will not be playing this when it is released.  I will recommend this game (only if) the developers get it together and work on the basics. It was 5/5 stars but now it's 2/5 stars in my book.  I WANT MY INTERSTELLAR MARINES BACK :'(Now to change course a little bit, I do recommend going here http://www.interstellarmarines.com/ to see what the developers have in mind for the final stage of the game. This link will take you to their home page where you can play the game in a more accurate setting.  These games are web-browser based.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								A very good start to a what seems to be a promising title--------------------------------The above review was made just shy of 3 years ago. And I still stand by the statement, "A good start". Because as of now, that’s all it seems to be. A start. This game has fallen into development hell. Even though there has been numerous updates to this game, they have been minor from a player stand point. Bugs were fixed. Maybe some textures were fixed. But as far as substantial, significant additions to the game, like new maps, new weapons, new game modes, new enemies.... not much has really happened. I follow them on Facebook, and they post the updates they are planning on. One update they had......they added a compass to the helmet HUD.....a compass....... This (small) addition did absolutely nothing to the gameplay. Another one, they gave the bots new skins. And added a CO2 meter. These are nice and dandy but very minor. Now look, I completely understand that this is a small development team. Im sure the guys are very talented in their skills. I know that they do not have a huge budget so things will take time. I completely understand that. But in all fairness, this game is just moving waaaaaay too slow. According to Wikipedia this game was announced in 2005! 2000 freaking 5!!!  And what has happened since then? From a consumer point of view, not much. Seriously. Where is this game?


YouTube™ Video: Interstellar Marines Trailer 1 

			Views: 101,575		

			Interstellar Marines is a video game unlike any on the market. The designers at Zero Point Software are embarking on a revolutionary journey, changing how video games are designed.		

This game showed a lot of promise. As I stated nearly 3 years ago. I know the development team is facing many challenges such as funding. But in all honestly, from the minor updates to slow development, I think one of the issues is bad direction/management. I think they focused on the minor, non essential details of the game and spent waaaaay too much time on them. This game showed a lot of potential. It really did. Unfortuantely, this game will be uninstalled.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall, it's an alright sci-fi FPS. The controls are fine, and the game dynamics are generally pretty great. One thing I didn't like was the lack of a objective reviewer or mini-map of somesort. When the next objective is relayed to you by voice, that is the only time you will be briefed on what you should do. If you failed to hear it, well, tough luck. You'll have to guess your way to the next objective. The different game modes are amusing enough. Elimination and coop provide extra entertainment and even the single player campaigns are worth playing through. The Neurogen episode is a particular favorite, as it incoroporates a certain horror element into the game. Everything is generally pitch black and you are left with just your torch to guide you through much of the game. But the best part is the psychotic androids which have gone berserk and are running around aimlessly throughout the corridors and rooms of the space ship. The sound effects help greatly, to instill a tiny sense of fear, mainly of the 'unknown'. The footsteps of the androids seem frantic at times and hearing them improved the atmosphere. When the androids see you they often run off to hide behind something and wait for you to come closer. Then they charge you with everything they have. It's great.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines is pre-alpha, it promises a lot and comes short so far (written on 11.02.2015 in case this review gets outdated)Positives? Movement is pretty solid, the two guns that are available feel pretty nice to use and it doesn't seem to be glitchy, floaty... It's immersive with what little variety it has.OH.The only real negative that stops the game completely is the fact that there's a LIMITED AMOUNT OF SERVERS and no way for you to setup a dedicated server as far as I know. If you want to do a full coop party of friends, you'll have to join a 3/4 server with reasonable ping, commit mutiny and "force" other players off the server. Oh, don't worry- that's the developer's fault for "focusing on developing the game" (from the forums) instead of making sure that people who bought the game can actually play it with other people.ENEMIES:The current enemies in the game are other players (multiplayer) and running robots that act like "sneaky" zombies or carry guns (co-op/singleplayer maps).DIFFICULTY:On lower than "Hard" difficulty, the game can feel a bit sloppy to be taken seriously. "Realistic" difficulty (maximum difficulty, above "Hard") makes enemy AI kill you in one or two hits, be it by gunshot or by a robosmack to the face.STEALTH?! I LOVE STEALTH!Eh. That's not really a thing, unless stealth to you is a "suppressant" that attracts half the robot population towards your location after you've killed one stray robot minding its own business. In multiplayer, there's a lot of maps with day/night cycles and weather effects that dirty your mask. You can actually take off the mask with H, but then all the HUD elements dissapear. This WOULD be very useful during rainy storms if you could tell your teammates from your enemies...OTHER THAN THAT: during the night in multiplayer, lights go on! Shoot them out! Stealth = darkness.I want to buy this game and I recommend it because it seems like a lot of fun. Just know that you probably won't get to coop with your friends since those servers are almost always occupied and that you need to go through the same painful process since servers have NO mapchange once you've exhausted the map 10 times in a row. I really hope they bring something interesting to this game later!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall the game is quite alright, it's fun to play it can really bring out the competetive side in you which is always really nice.Sadly the teamkill system is really annoying, for example if you are shooting at someone and a team mate runs in front of you resulting in you killing them you won't be able to kill that enemy you where shooting at because you will do no damage for 15 seconds, and for some reason this 15 seconds cooldown of no damage doesn't work against team mates so you can kill your whole team at the start of a round but if a team mate runs infront of you as you're shooting an enemy then you're screwed cause you're not getting that kill.Also the spectate system when you die is really annoying as it force switches you to the next person and there is no way of stopping this so if you're playing with a few friends and you want to watch them after you die you can forget about it, sometimes it does this the second you swap back and sometimes you get to watch your team mate play for about 15-20 sec tops before it force switches you. And the most annoying part about that is the fact that it sometimes switches you to a random player not the one next in line so you're gonna have to cycle throught to find your friend or that one team mate you wanted to watch.Other then that there isn't much to complain about more then that they really should add more guns, some type of granades, nightvision goggles would help a lot and add some more maps, but it is still early access so I do think that all of that and more will come in time. So far the game is really cool tho and I'd say it can be worth the 17 euros the game will cost at full price.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								So far this game seems to be getting along quite well, however it is on extremely early access which is apparent with things such as a lack of crouching, or lowering of the weapon whilst sprinting etc. (I Imagine leaning will also add more to the game) means that the game feels relatively fast paced at this moment in time compared to how it will be later.Because of the early access nature of the game, it is quite possible that something may go wrong in future development. However, the initial game, or at least what we can see of it is fairly well developed, with immersion factors in the recent update 7 adding quite a lot too the game. For starters, it brings about a reconcilliation between standard "Game" factors, and immersion breakers. IE: Most games will use hit detection via a little "X" over the crosshair. Marines however, does this by placing a small square over the enemy bodypart that you hit and only appears if your HUD is active. (Your HUD is controlled by your helmet being up or down and armour health/HP. Too much damage will disable it). Which is not only a unique feature, but really makes you feel like its an immersive futuristic experience.In fact, I'd say one of the parts they've really nailed on this game is the immersive experience, the fact that when it rains and my visor is up, I get rain drops splatter onto my helmet, or the fact that I have to use my laser sight to hipfire efficiently. It just feels good, and for someone who is a lover of Milsim it makes the game far more valuable and memorable too me.This game so far has amazing potential, and I look forward to seeing how it gets along. That being said, I recommend you wait a short while before buying, what we have now is brilliant, but it is quite barebones and so the later product can change in a multitude of ways. However if the devs keep it up the way they are, then I whole heartedly recommend the purchase and if you feel like you have cash to splurge, and want to try it now then don't let me stop you! The devs have been active, and I have no reason to doubt them, its obvious they are working hard! Truthfully its been awhile since I've seen such a polished game in early access!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I would not go as far as to say Interstellar Marines is one of a kind, its not, Everything it does has been done better before. However there simply are not enough slow paced stealth shooters out there to discount one like this. I like Interstellar Marines, I like the look, and I like the gameplay.  It does have a few issues though, at least for me.  I experienced a lot of lag even on the lowest ping multiplayer servers. and I also stuttered and lagged often even when my ping was only around 30 or 40. This only happened in multiplayer though and single player ran smoothly for me, even if it did quickly get boring.  There is not much content as it stands now. In my opinion now that the free week is going (2/12/15) the community may pick up a bit, giving the devs the boost they need to start working on the game more.  I have seen Interstellar Marines around for what seems like a long time, maybe even years and i was never interested in it until the free weekend. I am glad I got the chance to play it, even if it did not wow me enough for me to purchase it.   I still recommend it to you guys though, if you are looking for a good Early Access shooter, a Stealth based Shooter, or just for a shooter with an indie feel.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Visually, Interstellar Marines is beautiful; blurring and lighting effects are gorgeous. The audio is great as well, with lots of environment sounds to listen to. I don't have a good rig, but I get around 20 frames on 100 ping. Not bad. As far as gameplay goes, that game's not bad... generally. I mean, there are some nice features like running reloads that always come in handy. Movement feels pretty fluid, though there's no proning, which can be annoying.Immersion is very well done, with an actual animation for attaching a weapon's suppressor. You can see your helmet, and can raise and lower it, which I love. You just feel like you're an Interstellar Marine in space; it's awesome. I once played a game where we were in a large cargo bay, and happened to pass a large window looking in space. Pausing to look through the window, I saw earth. Standing there, looking through the window at our slowly orbiting planet, I was just in awe. It felt so real, like I was actually in space looking down on plant earth. On the dark side of earth, I could even see the millions of pinpricks of light the showed populated areas. I probably stood there for a full minute looking an earth and space, before my squadmates got my attention again.Now, for weapons. There are but three weapons available as of now, an assault rifle, a combat shotgun, and a submachine gun. They're all fun weapons and are visually gorgeous, but... there's only three of them. The assault rifle is basically a designated marksman weapon, because it has an unremoveable 4x optic. The combat shot does meager damage, about the same as the SMG near as I can tell, and that combined with semi-automatic fire makes it an unpopular weapon. This can be remedied by buffing the damage a bit, which ought to be done anyway, because it's a combat shotgun, The SMG is fine. Using automatic on the assault rifle and SMG is unrealistically innaccurate. Maybe things are different in the 22nd century, but you aim goes all over the place, and you really have to work the mouse while firing to land your shots.The multiplayer is good, but I personally enjoyed the co-op; a four man team advancing through an abandoned space station fending off attacks by defective robots. It's pretty rad.In the end? IM is a pretty fun game. Things can get a bit repetetive, but in general there's a lot of enjoyment to be had in outer space in the 22nd century. I've had the game for a few days, so I don't know what update frequency is like, though I've heard it's not stellar (pun intended). I hope to be proven wrong.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								A very good start to a what seems to be a promising title--------------------------------The above review was made just shy of 3 years ago. And I still stand by the statement, "A good start". Because as of now, that’s all it seems to be. A start. This game has fallen into development hell. Even though there has been numerous updates to this game, they have been minor from a player stand point. Bugs were fixed. Maybe some textures were fixed. But as far as substantial, significant additions to the game, like new maps, new weapons, new game modes, new enemies.... not much has really happened. I follow them on Facebook, and they post the updates they are planning on. One update they had......they added a compass to the helmet HUD.....a compass....... This (small) addition did absolutely nothing to the gameplay. Another one, they gave the bots new skins. And added a CO2 meter. These are nice and dandy but very minor. Now look, I completely understand that this is a small development team. Im sure the guys are very talented in their skills. I know that they do not have a huge budget so things will take time. I completely understand that. But in all fairness, this game is just moving waaaaaay too slow. According to Wikipedia this game was announced in 2005! 2000 freaking 5!!!  And what has happened since then? From a consumer point of view, not much. Seriously. Where is this game?


YouTube™ Video: Interstellar Marines Trailer 1 

			Views: 101,575		

			Interstellar Marines is a video game unlike any on the market. The designers at Zero Point Software are embarking on a revolutionary journey, changing how video games are designed.		

This game showed a lot of promise. As I stated nearly 3 years ago. I know the development team is facing many challenges such as funding. But in all honestly, from the minor updates to slow development, I think one of the issues is bad direction/management. I think they focused on the minor, non essential details of the game and spent waaaaay too much time on them. This game showed a lot of potential. It really did. Unfortuantely, this game will be uninstalled.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								So far this game seems to be getting along quite well, however it is on extremely early access which is apparent with things such as a lack of crouching, or lowering of the weapon whilst sprinting etc. (I Imagine leaning will also add more to the game) means that the game feels relatively fast paced at this moment in time compared to how it will be later.Because of the early access nature of the game, it is quite possible that something may go wrong in future development. However, the initial game, or at least what we can see of it is fairly well developed, with immersion factors in the recent update 7 adding quite a lot too the game. For starters, it brings about a reconcilliation between standard "Game" factors, and immersion breakers. IE: Most games will use hit detection via a little "X" over the crosshair. Marines however, does this by placing a small square over the enemy bodypart that you hit and only appears if your HUD is active. (Your HUD is controlled by your helmet being up or down and armour health/HP. Too much damage will disable it). Which is not only a unique feature, but really makes you feel like its an immersive futuristic experience.In fact, I'd say one of the parts they've really nailed on this game is the immersive experience, the fact that when it rains and my visor is up, I get rain drops splatter onto my helmet, or the fact that I have to use my laser sight to hipfire efficiently. It just feels good, and for someone who is a lover of Milsim it makes the game far more valuable and memorable too me.This game so far has amazing potential, and I look forward to seeing how it gets along. That being said, I recommend you wait a short while before buying, what we have now is brilliant, but it is quite barebones and so the later product can change in a multitude of ways. However if the devs keep it up the way they are, then I whole heartedly recommend the purchase and if you feel like you have cash to splurge, and want to try it now then don't let me stop you! The devs have been active, and I have no reason to doubt them, its obvious they are working hard! Truthfully its been awhile since I've seen such a polished game in early access!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been a Spearhead supporter since this game was a shooting range that ran on your browser. Hehe. I guess you either get it right or you don't. And as simple as that prototype was, it left me at awe. I have played shooters all of my life. From CS, Unreal, to MOH, COD2, MW and all of the Battlefields. The only thing that comes close to the level of authenticity in animation and visuals of this game is perhaps BF4. But IM still manages to strike a completely different and authentic feel that no other game has ever captured. With all the planned features and all of the things that they have created so far. I am greatly impressed. I really wish all of the best for this game and I want it to thrive and grow. I really am enjoying the co-op modes that have been added, and I am now seeing greater potential in this game. I have never, for a second, given up on Zero Point Software. I wish them the best of luck and hope to see this game in its full form, however long that might take. Great things take time, especially when you're not shackled by a Publisher. As a gamer, if you are looking for a shooter to satisfy your thirst for good emersion, you have arrived at the right place. You just need to be patient and let the game grow at a healthy rate.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								A great and ambitious game concept that is propably never going to see the light of day. When I first saw the prerendered "trailer" of the game I fell in love with the idea, the artwork and everything (I mean WALKING SHARKS how awesome is that?!).I was really exited when I found out the game recieved proper funding and even made it on to steam.But that exitement didnt last for long, because after a couple of months I realized that ZPS bit off more than they could chew.The development process is painfully slow and every ever so little step is sold as pure gold. I remember one video on their facebook page where they implemented "quite a complex movement and cover system" and bragged on about how awesome it is for TEN MINUTES, when it was just your basic-run-of-the-mill  walk-run-sprint-duck-movement.But thats only one of the many factors that made me lose my trust in the completion of the game.Another thing that boggles me is the fact, that the game has been on so many sales by now that propably every person who had just the slightest interest in the game bought it for a few bucks. So even if this game ever sees the light of day, AND its the game they promised AND its appreciated by the gaming community I dont see how there is any more money to be made because almost everyone interested in it allready owns it.I for one have not bought the game (and at this point I am rather glad I didnt). I played the so far released "content", and I did partake in the free to play weekend (but even then I hardly found any populated servers). But at the momement the game isnt more than a "tech demo" for the unity engine.And after the latest PR stunt they pulled (by now they have deleted the video) I have lost all hope in the game and the sanity of the team behind it.Guess the "hell week" was the prelude for the development hell the game is going to stew in once ZPS have run out of $$$

If you're making a game built for co-op, you better make sure two friends or more can play together without such a fuss. It's just the worst system I've ever seen.

Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is a diamond in the rough, but I believe, truthfully, that it is a superb concept with tremendous potential.I write this review as of the precipice of the release of update 25, which the devs say may happen tomorrow. I'm considering upgrading to "Speahead Addition" to help support the devs, who, by the way, are in dire need of support.It is a tactical game with eight maps. It has four or five coop missions and servers for all of them. It has fun multiplayer and servers up in all major regions, although you might want to get a few people to come and play with you, just in case you can't find many other players online.It also includes a survival scenerio called "Hell Week". Think of it as tactical fps hunger games. As of now there are three weapons, and assault rifle, smg, and pistol. Update 25 will add in tons of camos and skins which can be unlocked through CP points and leveling up. If you buy this game, know you are in it for the long haul and that you will need to find some friends to play with.With all of its faults, mostly from the struggles of development, the last thing Intersellar Marines needs is another negative review. And I don't intend to give it one.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Okay, I'm not bashing the game. It's just my opinion, based on the current state of game. 1. It's nothing but L4D2 with sci fi robots or Dead Space with Coop running around in mazes, mostly dark, chasing shadows.2. Weapons are pretty limited (only 2), so don't expect much "warfare" yet.3. The servers are mostly empty for me (I'm from India), so I get only EU servers and not much activity.4. If I am lucky, and do find a server sometime, it's only the 4 person coop, no PvP mode. I was more interested in PvP, but it's not there yet.5. The missions are pretty dull, as I mentioned, chasing robots and killing them or collecting "Keycards". Not very fun.6. The game gets laggy even on powerful systems, since the map isn't optimized well, so expect frequent FPS drops.But,1. The game is in Early Access stage, so yeah the content is VERY VERY limited, and you are paying to support the dev.2. More is to come in long term, but for now I personally do not find it very interesting. 3. Urmmm, I'm never buying another early access game again. This is just sad that you can release anything out of the door with barely any content, but atleast I can hope that I'm helping the devs so yeah, that's fine by me.At the current state, I do not recommend this game. Get your friends to play it maybe, then it could be fun.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is one I am hoping will one day see the light of day and get the recognition it deserves. It has a new Scifi feel to it and from what they have planned for the direction they will take this game in, it will be a must buy. However, there are not a lot of features in it now as it is still in very early alpha. (There is a load more features than when I bought it but someone new might not think so). What I am trying to say is, this small team of indie developers needs all the support and credit they deserve. And when people say that this game has been in development for 6 years, they are wrong. This game was originally supposed to come out in 2008 (I believe.) for console but sadly ZPS went bankrupt and were forced to cancel the game. This is a reboot of that franchise on an entirely new engine (That looks amazing graphics wise) and has only been in development for maybe 2 years. But considering that this is only an 8 or so person team, I am thoroughly impressed. If you are looking for a good scifi simulation shooter to pass the time then look no further. And imagine how happy you'll be when this game finshes? That way when the time comes you can say: "Look at this game. I supported it. Great job ZPS!" In all honesty, I play it at least 3 times a week. I say it is very good for an early alpha game and the direction they are heading is going to make it a lot better. They have a few singleplayer missions which you can play coop on, multiplayer TDM (which not many people play for some reason, but I digress) and Hell week which is essentially if you mixed The Hunger Games with guns and robots. Its an awesome PVP/PVE experience.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is fun. I'll just put that out there to start off. From a personal standpoint, I love the entire concept of it. A real gritty, tactical FPS. But before I go off on a tangeant like that, I'll sum up the pros and cons real quick:PROS:• Excellent gunplayLike, seriously. The weaponry is so satisfying. I got this game way back, back when there was just one weapon - the SMG. Even then, it was awesome. Now they have added two new weapons; an Assault Rifle, and a Pistol.. Thing. Either way, there's just something very satisfying about managing to headshot someone down a corridor, all sneaky beaky like.• EnvironmentsFrom the few maps there are, already it's clear a lot of time and effort is put into things. The attention to detail really shows, with some of the more lush/open maps (such as one that randomly changes setting every now and then) being extremely well done. The layout is also rather cool, as communicating with a squad and moving through a building feels very, very satisfying.• The Suit/UIFrom passive noises, to the dynamic of the HUD projected onto a proper model of the visor, the in-game UI feels very realistic, and looks badass. After being hit several times, the suit HUD even reacts, malfunctioning. This gives you a sound muffling effect as well, as if all electronics just shut down. And it pays off, resulting in a really immersive experience. The best part though? There's a key that lets you raise and lower the helmet visor - meaning if you wanna play without a HUD, you can.• AICombat AI is rather reactive; it could do with being better, but as it stands, it is still rather formidable and entertaining to play against. Even alone, they can be challenging. Countless times I've gotten to the end of a section, with only two combat training droids to go, only to be flanked by them at the last second. Not fun, but a testament to how much you have to pay attention in this game to noise, as well as visuals.CONS:• Not much contentAt the time of writing this review (03/10/2016), the only real missions are; a handful of "Search and Destroy" style levels where you have to shoot and destroy all combat training droids in a map, A few missions where you have to trigger switches while avoiding combat droids, and two story missions - one being where you have to break into a secure compound and extract information, the other where you have to extract information from a science lab station. While both are cool, the game does get stale after a while, however multiplayer PvP is definitely fun (although I suck at that).• Slow development timeFrom what I've heard, the game only has one full time developer due to financial issues. While that is rather.. Well, disappointing, it does testify as to how good this guy is. It's gonna take a lot of time for new content to be worked on (and at this rate, the game to be finished), but over the past couple of years there has been a few new additions - a couple of maps (rather large ones), and two new weapons. This definitely isn't a game to play if you want it right away, right now.• PlayerbaseThere tends to not be as many players nowadays, most likely due to the slow development time. This game isn't going to be finished any time soon. This does mean that there is only one or two full matches on at a time, if you are lucky, and they tend to be PvP. If you want to play on Co-op, then let your friends know; you are highly unlikely to find anyone online.• Server HostingWhile most servers tend to be really, really good, there are a few issues. The way server hosting works is, instead of having the ability to host your own server, you join an empty server and claim it as your own. This means you can change settings (such as password and player limit) and then you basically are happy as Larry. While that system works, it (used to be) very, very frustrating if you just wanted to play co-op with friends, and ended up with three other random people joining. And then your friends end up hosting their own, and the same goes on and on.SummaryThis game is good as it is, but it isn't exactly a full game. At the current price, I would recommend it. However, if you are after a game that is going to be done soon, or prefer not to be patient and see the development process through, I suggest looking elsewhere. This game has a lot of potential ahead of it, and while a lot of setbacks have overcome the developers, I am sure that given time they will make something very playabe, very decent, and very fun.That and the helmet feature is f***in awesome.
